<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> style="padding:0 0.5em;" <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> <b><a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_and_territory_mottos" title="List of U.S. state and territory mottos">Motto</a></b> 
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> style="padding:0 0.5em;" <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> <i>Fatti maschii, parole femine</i> <br /> Literally: manly deeds, womanly words <br /> Officially: strong deeds, gentle words

<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> style="padding:0 0.5em;" <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_U.S._state_poems&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of U.S. state poems (page does not exist)">Poem</a></b> 
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> style="padding:0 0.5em;" <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> "Maryland, My Maryland" by <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Ryder_Randall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Ryder Randall (page does not exist)">James Ryder Randall</a>

 





<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> style="padding:0 0.5em;" <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> <b>Slogan(s)</b> 
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> style="padding:0 0.5em;" <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> Maryland of Opportunity



<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> style="padding:0 0.5em;" <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> <b><a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._state_songs" title="List of U.S. state songs">Song(s)</a></b> 
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> style="padding:0 0.5em;" <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:!&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:! (page does not exist)">Template:!</a> <a href="/wiki/Maryland,_My_Maryland" title="Maryland, My Maryland">Maryland, My Maryland</a>









<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding:0 0.5em;"> <hr />
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding:0 0.5em; text-align:center; font-size:13px;"> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Numbered_highways_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Numbered highways in the United States (page does not exist)">Route marker(s)</a></b>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding:0.5em 0.5em;"> <center><a href="/wiki/File:MD_Route_4.svg" title="File:MD Route 4.svg">Maryland Route Marker</a></center>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding:0 0.5em;"> <hr />
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding:0 0.5em; text-align:center; font-size:13px;"> <b><a href="/wiki/50_State_Quarters" title="50 State Quarters">State Quarter</a></b>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding:0.5em 0.5em;"> <center><a href="/wiki/File:2000_MD_Proof.png" title="File:2000 MD Proof.png">Quarter of Maryland</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="padding:0.5em 0.5em; text-align:center;"> <b>Released in 2000</b>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2"> <hr />
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td colspan="2" style="text-align:center; padding:0.5em 0.5em; font-size:13px;"> <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Lists_of_United_States_state_insignia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Lists of United States state insignia (page does not exist)">Lists of United States state insignia</a></b>
</td></tr></table>
<p><b>Maryland</b> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:IPAc-en&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:IPAc-en (page does not exist)">Template:IPAc-en</a><sup id="cite_ref-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=U.S._state&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U.S. state (page does not exist)">U.S. state</a> located in the <a href="/wiki/Mid-Atlantic_states" title="Mid-Atlantic states">Mid-Atlantic region</a> of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>, bordering <a href="/wiki/Virginia" title="Virginia">Virginia</a>, <a href="/wiki/West_Virginia" title="West Virginia">West Virginia</a>, and  <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> to its south and west; <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a> to its north; and <a href="/wiki/Delaware" title="Delaware">Delaware</a> to its east. Maryland was the seventh state to ratify the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Constitution" title="United States Constitution">United States Constitution</a>, and has three occasionally used nicknames: the <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryland_400&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryland 400 (page does not exist)">Old Line State</a></i>, the <i>Free State</i>, and the <i><a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay" title="Chesapeake Bay">Chesapeake Bay</a> State</i>.
</p><p>Maryland is <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_and_territories_by_area" title="List of U.S. states and territories by area">one of the smallest states</a> in terms of area, as well as one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_by_population_density" title="List of U.S. states by population density">most densely populated</a> states of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>.  The state's largest city is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore (page does not exist)">Baltimore</a>, and its capital is <a href="/wiki/Annapolis,_Maryland" title="Annapolis, Maryland">Annapolis</a>. Although the state is officially claimed to be named after <a href="/w/index.php?title=Henrietta_Maria_of_France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Henrietta Maria of France (page does not exist)">Queen Henrietta Maria</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-2">[2]</a></sup> many historians believe Maryland was named after <a href="/wiki/Mary_(mother_of_Jesus)" title="Mary (mother of Jesus)">Mary</a>, the mother of <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a>, by <a href="/wiki/George_Calvert,_1st_Lord_Baltimore" title="George Calvert, 1st Lord Baltimore" class="mw-redirect">George Calvert, 1st Lord Baltimore</a> prior to his death in 1632.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup> The original intent may never be known.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup>
Maryland has the highest median household income, making it the <a href="/wiki/List_of_U.S._states_by_income" title="List of U.S. states by income">wealthiest state</a> in the nation.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup>
</p>
<div id="toc" class="toc"><div id="toctitle"><h2>Contents</h2></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Maryland has an area of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and is comparable in overall area with the <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">European</a> country of <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[6]</a></sup> It is the 42nd largest and 9th smallest state and is closest in size to the state of <a href="/wiki/Hawaii" title="Hawaii">Hawaii</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>), the next smallest state. The next largest state, its neighbor <a href="/wiki/West_Virginia" title="West Virginia">West Virginia</a>, is almost twice the size of Maryland (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>).
</p><p>Maryland possesses a variety of <a href="/wiki/Topography" title="Topography">topography</a> within its borders, contributing to its nickname <i>America in Miniature</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> It ranges from sandy <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dunes&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dunes (page does not exist)">dunes</a> dotted with seagrass in the east, to low marshlands teeming with wildlife and large <a href="/wiki/Taxodium" title="Taxodium">bald cypress</a> near the Chesapeake Bay, to gently rolling hills of <a href="/wiki/Oak" title="Oak">oak</a> forests in the <a href="/wiki/Piedmont_(United_States)" title="Piedmont (United States)">Piedmont Region</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Pine" title="Pine">pine</a> groves in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_mountains_in_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of mountains in Maryland (page does not exist)">mountains</a> to the west.
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Deep_Creek_Lake_Maryland_Panoramic_View.jpg" title="File:Deep Creek Lake Maryland Panoramic View.jpg">File:Deep Creek Lake Maryland Panoramic View.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A panoramic view of <a href="/wiki/Deep_Creek_Lake" title="Deep Creek Lake">Deep Creek Lake</a> and the surrounding <a href="/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains" title="Appalachian Mountains">Appalachian Mountains</a> in <a href="/wiki/Garrett_County,_Maryland" title="Garrett County, Maryland">Garrett County</a>.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:MDGeoReg.PNG" title="File:MDGeoReg.PNG">File:MDGeoReg.PNG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Physical regions of Maryland</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:ChesapeakeTidalWetlands.jpg" title="File:ChesapeakeTidalWetlands.jpg">File:ChesapeakeTidalWetlands.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Tidal wetlands of the <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay" title="Chesapeake Bay">Chesapeake Bay</a>, the largest <a href="/wiki/Estuary" title="Estuary">estuary</a> in the United States and the largest water feature in Maryland.</div></div></div>
<p>Maryland is bounded on its north by <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>, on its west by <a href="/wiki/West_Virginia" title="West Virginia">West Virginia</a>, on its east by <a href="/wiki/Delaware" title="Delaware">Delaware</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a>, and on its south, across the <a href="/wiki/Potomac_River" title="Potomac River">Potomac River</a>, by West Virginia and <a href="/wiki/Virginia" title="Virginia">Virginia</a>. The mid-portion of this border is interrupted by <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, which sits on land originally part of <a href="/wiki/Montgomery_County,_Maryland" title="Montgomery County, Maryland">Montgomery</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prince_George%27s_County,_Maryland" title="Prince George's County, Maryland">Prince George's</a> counties, including the town of <a href="/wiki/Georgetown,_D.C." title="Georgetown, D.C." class="mw-redirect">Georgetown, Maryland</a>, that was ceded to the Federal Government in 1790 to form the <a href="/wiki/District_of_Columbia" title="District of Columbia" class="mw-redirect">District of Columbia</a>. (The <a href="/wiki/Virginia" title="Virginia">Commonwealth of Virginia</a> gave land south of the Potomac, including the town of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alexandria,_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alexandria, Virginia (page does not exist)">Alexandria, Virginia</a>, however Virginia retroceded its portion in 1846). The <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay" title="Chesapeake Bay">Chesapeake Bay</a> nearly bisects the state and the counties east of the bay are known collectively as the <i><a href="/wiki/Eastern_Shore_of_Maryland" title="Eastern Shore of Maryland">Eastern Shore</a></i>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Patapsco_fg01.jpg" title="File:Patapsco fg01.jpg">File:Patapsco fg01.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Patapsco_River" title="Patapsco River">Patapsco River</a> includes the famous <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thomas_Viaduct&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thomas Viaduct (page does not exist)">Thomas Viaduct</a> and is part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Patapsco_Valley_State_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Patapsco Valley State Park (page does not exist)">Patapsco Valley State Park</a>. Later, the river forms the <a href="/wiki/Inner_Harbor" title="Inner Harbor">Inner Harbor</a> as it empties into the <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay" title="Chesapeake Bay">Chesapeake Bay</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Most of the state's waterways are part of the Chesapeake Bay watershed, with the exceptions of a tiny portion of extreme western <a href="/wiki/Garrett_County,_Maryland" title="Garrett County, Maryland">Garrett County</a> (drained by the <a href="/wiki/Youghiogheny_River" title="Youghiogheny River">Youghiogheny River</a> as part of the watershed of the <a href="/wiki/Mississippi_River" title="Mississippi River">Mississippi River</a>), the eastern half of Worcester County (which drains into Maryland's Atlantic coastal bays), and a small portion of the state's northeast corner (which drains into the <a href="/wiki/Delaware_River" title="Delaware River">Delaware River</a> watershed). So prominent is the Chesapeake in Maryland's geography and economic life that there has been periodic agitation to change the state's official nickname to the <i><b>Bay State</b></i>, a nickname that has been used by <a href="/wiki/Massachusetts" title="Massachusetts">Massachusetts</a> for decades.
</p><p>The highest point in Maryland, with an elevation of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, is <a href="/wiki/Backbone_Mountain" title="Backbone Mountain">Hoye Crest on Backbone Mountain</a>, in the southwest corner of <a href="/wiki/Garrett_County,_Maryland" title="Garrett County, Maryland">Garrett County</a>, near the border with West Virginia and near the headwaters of the North Branch of the Potomac River.  Close to the small town of <a href="/wiki/Hancock,_Maryland" title="Hancock, Maryland">Hancock</a>, in western Maryland, about two-thirds of the way across the state, there is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> between its borders. This geographical curiosity makes Maryland the narrowest state,{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} bordered by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mason-Dixon_Line&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mason-Dixon Line (page does not exist)">Mason-Dixon Line</a> to the north, and the northwards-arching <a href="/wiki/Potomac_River" title="Potomac River">Potomac River</a> to the south.
</p><p>Portions of Maryland are included in various official and unofficial geographic regions. For example, the <a href="/wiki/Delmarva_Peninsula" title="Delmarva Peninsula">Delmarva Peninsula</a> is composed of the Eastern Shore counties of Maryland, the entire <a href="/w/index.php?title=State_of_Delaware&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="State of Delaware (page does not exist)">state of Delaware</a>, and the two counties that make up the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Shore_of_Virginia" title="Eastern Shore of Virginia">Eastern Shore of Virginia</a>, whereas the westernmost counties of Maryland are considered part of <a href="/wiki/Appalachia" title="Appalachia">Appalachia</a>. Much of the Baltimore–Washington corridor lies just south of the Piedmont in the Coastal Plain,<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> though it straddles the border between the two regions.
</p><p>There are no natural lakes,<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> though there are numerous <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pond&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pond (page does not exist)">ponds</a>. During the latter <a href="/wiki/Ice_Age" title="Ice Age" class="mw-redirect">Ice Ages</a>, the glaciers did not reach as far south as Maryland, and therefore they did not carve out the deep natural lakes that exist in states farther north. There are numerous man-made lakes, the largest of these being the <a href="/wiki/Deep_Creek_Lake" title="Deep Creek Lake">Deep Creek Lake</a>, a reservoir in <a href="/wiki/Garrett_County,_Maryland" title="Garrett County, Maryland">Garrett County</a> in westernmost Maryland. The lack of a glacial history also accounts for Maryland's soil, which is sandier and muddier than the rocky soils farther to the north and northeast.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3>
<p>Maryland has a wide array of climates, due to local variances in elevation, proximity to water, and protection from colder weather due to <a href="/wiki/Katabatic_wind" title="Katabatic wind">downslope winds</a>.
</p><p>The eastern half of Maryland lies on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Atlantic_Coastal_Plain&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Atlantic Coastal Plain (page does not exist)">Atlantic Coastal Plain</a>, with very flat topography and very sandy or muddy soil. This region has a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Humid_subtropical_climate&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Humid subtropical climate (page does not exist)">humid subtropical climate</a> (<a href="/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification" title="Köppen climate classification">Köppen</a> <i>Cfa</i>), with hot, humid summers and a short, mild to cool winter; it falls under USDA <a href="/wiki/Hardiness_zone" title="Hardiness zone">Hardiness zone</a> 8a.<sup id="cite_ref-Arbor_Day_Foundation_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arbor_Day_Foundation-10">[10]</a></sup> This region includes the cities of <a href="/wiki/Ocean_City,_Maryland" title="Ocean City, Maryland">Ocean City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Salisbury,_Maryland" title="Salisbury, Maryland">Salisbury</a>, <a href="/wiki/Annapolis" title="Annapolis" class="mw-redirect">Annapolis</a>, and the southern and eastern suburbs of Washington, D.C. and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore (page does not exist)">Baltimore</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Sunset_over_the_marsh_at_Cardinal_Cove_-_NOAA.jpg" title="File:Sunset over the marsh at Cardinal Cove - NOAA.jpg">File:Sunset over the marsh at Cardinal Cove - NOAA.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sunset over a marsh at Cardinal Cove on the <a href="/wiki/Patuxent_River" title="Patuxent River">Patuxent River</a></div></div></div>
<p>Beyond this region lies the <a href="/wiki/Piedmont_(United_States)" title="Piedmont (United States)">Piedmont</a>, with average seasonal snowfall totals generally exceeding <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> and, as part of USDA Hardiness zones 7b and 7a,<sup id="cite_ref-Arbor_Day_Foundation_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arbor_Day_Foundation-10">[10]</a></sup> temperatures below <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> are less rare. From the <a href="/wiki/Cumberland_Valley" title="Cumberland Valley">Cumberland Valley</a> on westward, the climate begins to transition to a <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">humid continental climate</a> (Köppen <i>Dfa</i>). This region includes northern and western greater Baltimore, <a href="/wiki/Westminster,_Maryland" title="Westminster, Maryland">Westminster</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gaithersburg,_Maryland" title="Gaithersburg, Maryland">Gaithersburg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frederick,_Maryland" title="Frederick, Maryland">Frederick</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hagerstown,_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hagerstown, Maryland (page does not exist)">Hagerstown</a>.
</p><p>Farther into western Maryland, the higher elevations of <a href="/wiki/Allegany_County,_Maryland" title="Allegany County, Maryland">Allegany County</a> and <a href="/wiki/Garrett_County,_Maryland" title="Garrett County, Maryland">Garrett County</a> display more characteristics of the humid continental zone, due in part to elevation, and are more similar to that of south-central Pennsylvania, including the cities of <a href="/wiki/Cumberland,_Maryland" title="Cumberland, Maryland">Cumberland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frostburg,_Maryland" title="Frostburg, Maryland">Frostburg</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Oakland,_Maryland" title="Oakland, Maryland">Oakland</a>. They fall under USDA Hardiness zones 6b and below.<sup id="cite_ref-Arbor_Day_Foundation_10-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arbor_Day_Foundation-10">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>Precipitation in the state is characteristic of the East Coast. Annual rainfall ranges from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> with more in higher elevations. Nearly every part of Maryland receives <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> per month of rain. Average annual snowfall varies from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in the coastal areas to over <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in the western mountains of the state.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because of its location near the <a href="/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States" title="East Coast of the United States">Atlantic Coast</a>, Maryland is somewhat vulnerable to <a href="/wiki/Tropical_cyclones" title="Tropical cyclones" class="mw-redirect">tropical cyclones</a>, although the <a href="/wiki/Delmarva_Peninsula" title="Delmarva Peninsula">Delmarva Peninsula</a>, and the outer banks of <a href="/wiki/North_Carolina" title="North Carolina">North Carolina</a> to the south provide a large buffer, such that a strike from a major hurricane (category 3 or above) is not very likely but is not impossible. More often, Maryland might get the remnants of a tropical system which has already come ashore and released most of its wind energy. Maryland averages around 30–40 days of thunderstorms a year, and averages around six tornado strikes annually.<sup id="cite_ref-Annual_average_number_of_tornadoes_12-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Annual_average_number_of_tornadoes-12">[12]</a></sup>
&lt;center&gt;
</p>
<table class="wikitable">
<tr>

</th>

</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f8f3ca; color:#000;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a><br /><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f8f3ca; color:#000;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a><br /><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f8f3ca; color:#000;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a><br /><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f8f3ca; color:#000;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a><br /><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>
</td></tr>
<tr>
<th style="background:#f8f3ca; color:#000; height:16px;"> Frederick
</th>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f8f3ca; color:#000;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a><br /><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f8f3ca; color:#000;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a><br /><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f8f3ca; color:#000;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a><br /><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>
</td>
<td style="text-align:center; background:#f8f3ca; color:#000;"> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a><br /><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>
</td>

</td>

</td>

</th>

</td>

<tr>
<td colspan="13" style="text-align:center;font-size:90%;background:#E8EAFA;"><i><sup id="cite_ref-NOAA_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA-13">[13]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NOAA_Cumberland_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA_Cumberland-15">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NOAA_Frederick_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA_Frederick-17">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NOAA_Baltimore_downtown_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA_Baltimore_downtown-18">[18]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NOAA_Ocean_City_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NOAA_Ocean_City-19">[19]</a></sup></i>
</td></tr></table>
</center>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Flora">Flora</span></h3>
<p>As is typical of states on the <a href="/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States" title="East Coast of the United States">East Coast</a>, Maryland's plant life is abundant and healthy. A good dose of annual precipitation helps to support many types of plants, including <a href="/wiki/Seagrass" title="Seagrass">seagrass</a> and various <a href="/wiki/Phragmites" title="Phragmites">reeds</a> at the smaller end of the spectrum to the gigantic <a href="/wiki/Wye_Oak" title="Wye Oak">Wye Oak</a>, a huge example of <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_oak&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White oak (page does not exist)">White oak</a>, the state tree, which can grow in excess of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> tall.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Middle_Atlantic_coastal_forests&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Middle Atlantic coastal forests (page does not exist)">Middle Atlantic coastal forests</a>, typical of the southeastern <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_coastal_plain" title="Atlantic coastal plain">Atlantic coastal plain</a>, grow around Chesapeake Bay and on the <a href="/wiki/Delmarva_Peninsula" title="Delmarva Peninsula">Delmarva Peninsula</a>. Moving west, a mixture of <a href="/wiki/Northeastern_coastal_forests" title="Northeastern coastal forests">Northeastern coastal forests</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Southeastern_mixed_forests&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Southeastern mixed forests (page does not exist)">Southeastern mixed forests</a> cover the central part of the state. The <a href="/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains" title="Appalachian Mountains">Appalachian Mountains</a> of western Maryland are home to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Appalachian-Blue_Ridge_forests&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Appalachian-Blue Ridge forests (page does not exist)">Appalachian-Blue Ridge forests</a>. These give way to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Appalachian_mixed_mesophytic_forests&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Appalachian mixed mesophytic forests (page does not exist)">Appalachian mixed mesophytic forests</a> near the West Virginia border.<sup id="cite_ref-ecoregions_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ecoregions-20">[20]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many foreign species are cultivated in the state, some as ornamentals, others as novelty species. Included among these are the <a href="/wiki/Lagerstroemia" title="Lagerstroemia">Crape Myrtle</a>, <a href="/wiki/Italian_Cypress" title="Italian Cypress" class="mw-redirect">Italian Cypress</a>, <a href="/wiki/Live_oak" title="Live oak">live oak</a> in the warmer parts of the state,<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup> and even <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hardy_palms&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hardy palms (page does not exist)">hardy palm trees</a> in the warmer central and eastern parts of the state.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> USDA plant <a href="/wiki/Hardiness_zone" title="Hardiness zone">hardiness zones</a> in the state range from Zones 5 and 6 in the extreme western part of the state to Zone 7 in the central part, and Zone 8 around the southern part of the coast, the bay area, and parts of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore_Metropolitan_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore Metropolitan Area (page does not exist)">metropolitan Baltimore</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Arbor_Day_Foundation_10-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Arbor_Day_Foundation-10">[10]</a></sup> Invasive plant species, such as <a href="/wiki/Kudzu" title="Kudzu">kudzu</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tree_of_heaven&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tree of heaven (page does not exist)">tree of heaven</a>, <a href="/wiki/Multiflora_rose" title="Multiflora rose" class="mw-redirect">multiflora rose</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Microstegium_vimineum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Microstegium vimineum (page does not exist)">Japanese stiltgrass</a>, stifle growth of endemic plant life.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup> Maryland's state  flower, the <a href="/wiki/Rudbeckia_hirta" title="Rudbeckia hirta">Black-eyed Susan</a>, grows in abundance in wild flower groups throughout the state.  The state insect, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore_Checkerspot_Butterfly&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore Checkerspot Butterfly (page does not exist)">Baltimore Checkerspot Butterfly</a>, is not common as it is near the southern edge of its range.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Maryland_birds&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Maryland birds (page does not exist)">435 species of birds</a> have been reported from Maryland.<sup id="cite_ref-MRC_25-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MRC-25">[25]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fauna">Fauna</span></h3>
<p>The state harbors a great number of <a href="/wiki/Deer" title="Deer">deer</a>, especially in the woody and mountainous west of the state, and overpopulation can become a problem from year-to-year.  Mammals can be found ranging from the mountains in the west to the central areas and include bears,<sup id="cite_ref-Maryland_Wildlife_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Maryland_Wildlife-26">[26]</a></sup> bobcats,<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> foxes, coyote,<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> raccoons, and otters.<sup id="cite_ref-Maryland_Wildlife_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Maryland_Wildlife-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Assateague_Island_horses_August_2009_4.jpg" title="File:Assateague Island horses August 2009 4.jpg">File:Assateague Island horses August 2009 4.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A wild <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chincoteague_Pony&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chincoteague Pony (page does not exist)">Chincoteague Pony</a> on <a href="/wiki/Assateague_Island" title="Assateague Island">Assateague Island</a></div></div></div>
<p>There is a population of rare<sup id="cite_ref-Maryland_Wildlife_26-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Maryland_Wildlife-26">[26]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> wild horses found on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Assateague&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Assateague (page does not exist)">Assateague</a> Island. Every year during the last week of July, wild horses are captured and waded across a shallow bay for sale at <a href="/wiki/Chincoteague,_Virginia" title="Chincoteague, Virginia">Chincoteague, Virginia</a>. This conservation technique ensures the tiny island is not overrun by the horses.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}} The ponies and their sale were popularized by the children's book, <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Misty_of_Chincoteague&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Misty of Chincoteague (page does not exist)">Misty of Chincoteague</a>.</i> They are believed to be descended from horses who escaped from shipwrecks.
</p><p>The purebred <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay_Retriever" title="Chesapeake Bay Retriever">Chesapeake Bay Retriever</a> dog was bred specifically for water sports, hunting and search and rescue in the Chesapeake area.<sup id="cite_ref-Maryland1_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Maryland1-30">[30]</a></sup> In 1878 the Chesapeake Bay Retriever was the first individual retriever breed recognized by the <a href="/wiki/American_Kennel_Club" title="American Kennel Club">American Kennel Club</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Maryland1_30-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Maryland1-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p><p>Maryland's reptile and amphibian population is led by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Diamondback_Terrapin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Diamondback Terrapin (page does not exist)">Diamondback Terrapin</a> turtle, which was adopted as the mascot of <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Maryland,_College_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Maryland, College Park (page does not exist)">University of Maryland, College Park</a>. The state is the territory of the <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_Oriole" title="Baltimore Oriole">Baltimore Oriole</a>, which is the official state bird and mascot of the MLB team the <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_Orioles" title="Baltimore Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environmental_awareness">Environmental awareness</span></h3>
<p>In 2007, Forbes.com rated Maryland as the fifth "Greenest" state in the country behind three of the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_States" title="Pacific States">Pacific States</a> and Vermont. Maryland ranks 40th in total energy consumption nationwide, and it managed less toxic waste per capita than all but six states in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> In April 2007 Maryland joined the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regional_Greenhouse_Gas_Initiative&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative (page does not exist)">Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative</a> (RGGI)—a regional initiative formed by all of the Northeastern states, Washington D.C., and three Canadian provinces to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Earthquakes">Earthquakes</span></h3>
<p>Earthquakes in Maryland are infrequent due to its distance<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Quantify&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Quantify (page does not exist)">Template:Quantify</a> from tectonic plates and seismic/earthquake zones. The earthquakes that do occur are small, but may be felt over wide areas.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Moment_magnitude_scale" title="Moment magnitude scale">M</a>5.8 <a href="/w/index.php?title=2011_Virginia_earthquake&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2011 Virginia earthquake (page does not exist)">Virginia earthquake in 2011</a> was felt moderately throughout Maryland. Buildings in the state are not well-designed for earthquakes and can suffer damage easily.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="17th_century">17th century</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Calvertcecil.jpg" title="File:Calvertcecil.jpg">File:Calvertcecil.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Cecilius_Calvert,_2nd_Baron_Baltimore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cecilius Calvert, 2nd Baron Baltimore (page does not exist)">Cecilius Calvert, 2nd Baron Baltimore</a>, 1st Proprietor of the Maryland colony.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1629, <a href="/wiki/George_Calvert,_1st_Lord_Baltimore" title="George Calvert, 1st Lord Baltimore" class="mw-redirect">George Calvert, 1st Lord Baltimore</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Peerage_of_Ireland" title="Peerage of Ireland">Peerage of Ireland</a>, fresh from his failure further north with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_(island)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Newfoundland (island) (page does not exist)">Newfoundland's</a> <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Avalon" title="Province of Avalon">Province of Avalon</a> colony, applied to <a href="/wiki/Charles_I_of_England" title="Charles I of England">Charles I</a> for a royal charter for what was to become the <a href="/wiki/Province_of_Maryland" title="Province of Maryland">Province of Maryland</a>. Calvert's interest in creating a colony derived from his <a href="/w/index.php?title=Catholicism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Catholicism (page does not exist)">Catholicism</a> and his desire for the creation of a haven in the New World for Catholics. He wanted a share of fortunes, such as those made by the sale of the commodity <a href="/wiki/Tobacco" title="Tobacco">tobacco</a> in Virginia, and hoped to recoup some of the financial losses he had sustained in his earlier colonial venture in Newfoundland.<sup id="cite_ref-books.google_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Stewart_1967_42.E2.80.9343_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stewart_1967_42.E2.80.9343-36">[36]</a></sup>
</p><p>George Calvert died in April 1632, but a charter for "Maryland Colony" (in <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a>, <i>Terra Maria</i>) was granted to his son, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cecilius_Calvert,_2nd_Baron_Baltimore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cecilius Calvert, 2nd Baron Baltimore (page does not exist)">Cæcilius Calvert, 2nd Lord Baltimore</a>, on June 20, 1632. The new colony may have been named in honor of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Henrietta_Maria_of_France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Henrietta Maria of France (page does not exist)">Henrietta Maria of France</a>, wife of Charles I of England.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> The name recorded in the charter was phrased <i>"Terra Mariae, anglice</i>, Maryland". The English name was preferred over the Latin due in part to the undesired association of "Mariae" with the Spanish Jesuit <a href="/w/index.php?title=Juan_de_Mariana&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Juan de Mariana (page does not exist)">Juan de Mariana</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Inquisition" title="Inquisition">Inquisition</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-books.google_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-books.google-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Stewart_1967_42.E2.80.9343_36-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stewart_1967_42.E2.80.9343-36">[36]</a></sup> The Calvert family, who founded Maryland partly as a refuge for English Catholics, sought enactment of the law to protect Catholic settlers and those of other religions that did not conform to the dominant Anglicanism of England and her colonies. This led to the <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Toleration_Act" title="Maryland Toleration Act">Maryland Toleration Act</a> in 1649. It was the first law ever to guarantee the right to worship regardless of denomination.
</p><p>To try to gain settlers, Maryland used what is known as the <a href="/wiki/Headright_system" title="Headright system" class="mw-redirect">headright system</a>, which originated in <a href="/wiki/Jamestown,_Virginia" title="Jamestown, Virginia">Jamestown</a>. Settlers were given 50 acres of land for each person they brought into the colony, whether as settler, <a href="/wiki/Indentured_servant" title="Indentured servant">indentured servant</a> or <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States" title="Slavery in the United States">slave</a>.
</p><p>On March 25, 1634, Lord Baltimore sent the first colonists into this area. Although most of the settlers were <a href="/wiki/Protestants" title="Protestants" class="mw-redirect">Protestants</a>, Maryland soon became one of the few regions in the <a href="/wiki/British_Empire" title="British Empire">English Empire</a> where <a href="/wiki/Catholics" title="Catholics" class="mw-redirect">Catholics</a> held the highest positions of political authority. Maryland was also a key destination for transport of tens of thousands of English convicts to work as indentured servants.
</p><p>The royal charter granted Maryland the land north of the entire length of the <a href="/wiki/Potomac_River" title="Potomac River">Potomac River</a> up to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=40th_parallel_north&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="40th parallel north (page does not exist)">40th parallel</a>. A problem arose when <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">Charles II</a> granted a charter for <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a>. The grant defined Pennsylvania's southern border as identical to Maryland's northern border, the 40th parallel. But the terms of the grant clearly indicate that Charles II and <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Penn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Penn (page does not exist)">William Penn</a> assumed the 40th parallel would pass close to <a href="/wiki/New_Castle,_Delaware" title="New Castle, Delaware">New Castle, Delaware</a> when it falls north of <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>, the site of which Penn had already selected for his colony's capital city. Negotiations ensued after the problem was discovered in 1681.
</p><p>A compromise proposed by Charles II in 1682, which might have resolved the issue, was undermined by Penn's receiving the additional grant of what is now Delaware&#160;— which previously had been part of Maryland.<sup id="cite_ref-hubbard_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hubbard-38">[38]</a></sup> The dispute remained unresolved for nearly a century, carried on by the descendants of William Penn and Lord Baltimore—the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cecilius_Calvert,_2nd_Baron_Baltimore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cecilius Calvert, 2nd Baron Baltimore (page does not exist)">Calvert family</a>, which controlled Maryland, and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Penn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Penn (page does not exist)">Penn family</a>, which controlled Pennsylvania.<sup id="cite_ref-hubbard_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hubbard-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="18th_century">18th century</span></h3>
<p>The conflict led to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Cresap%27s_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cresap's War (page does not exist)">Cresap's War</a> (also known as the Conojocular War), a border conflict between Pennsylvania and Maryland, fought in the 1730s. Hostilities erupted in 1730 with a series of violent incidents prompted by disputes over property rights and law enforcement, and escalated through the first half of the decade, culminating in the deployment of military forces by Maryland in 1736 and by Pennsylvania in 1737. The armed phase of the conflict ended in May 1738 with the intervention of King George II, who compelled the negotiation of a cease-fire. A provisional agreement had been established in 1732.<sup id="cite_ref-hubbard_38-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hubbard-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p><p>Negotiations continued until a final agreement was signed in 1760. The agreement defined Maryland's border with what is now Delaware as well as Pennsylvania. The border between Maryland and Pennsylvania was defined as the line of latitude <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> south of the southernmost house of Philadelphia, a line now known as the  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mason-Dixon_Line&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mason-Dixon Line (page does not exist)">Mason-Dixon Line</a>. Maryland's border with Delaware was based on a <a href="/wiki/Transpeninsular_Line" title="Transpeninsular Line">Transpeninsular Line</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Twelve-Mile_Circle" title="Twelve-Mile Circle">Twelve-Mile Circle</a> around New Castle.<sup id="cite_ref-hubbard_38-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-hubbard-38">[38]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ft._Henry_bombardement_1814.jpg" title="File:Ft. Henry bombardement 1814.jpg">File:Ft. Henry bombardement 1814.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">An artist's rendering of the bombardment of <a href="/wiki/Fort_McHenry" title="Fort McHenry">Fort McHenry</a> in Baltimore, which inspired the composition of the song, "<a href="/wiki/Star_Spangled_Banner" title="Star Spangled Banner" class="mw-redirect">Star Spangled Banner</a>".</div></div></div>
<p>After <a href="/wiki/Virginia" title="Virginia">Virginia</a> made <a href="/wiki/Anglicanism" title="Anglicanism">Anglicanism</a> the established religion in the colony, numerous Puritans migrated from Virginia to Maryland. They were given land for a settlement called Providence (now Annapolis).  In 1650, the Puritans revolted against the proprietary government and set up a new government that prohibited both <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Catholic_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Catholic Church (page does not exist)">Catholicism</a> and Anglicanism. In March 1654, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=C%C3%A6cilius_Calvert,_2nd_Baron_Baltimore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Cæcilius Calvert, 2nd Baron Baltimore (page does not exist)">2nd Lord Baltimore</a> sent an army under the command of Governor <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Stone_(Maryland_governor)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Stone (Maryland governor) (page does not exist)">William Stone</a> to put down the revolt, but his forces were decisively defeated by a <a href="/wiki/Puritan" title="Puritan">Puritan</a> army near Annapolis in what was to be known as the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_the_Severn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battle of the Severn (page does not exist)">Battle of the Severn</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the persecution of Catholics in the <a href="/wiki/Puritan" title="Puritan">Puritan</a> revolt, Protestants burned down all of the original Catholic churches of southern Maryland. The Puritan revolt lasted until 1658, when the Calvert family regained control of the colony and re-enacted the Toleration Act. However, after England's "<a href="/wiki/Glorious_Revolution" title="Glorious Revolution">Glorious Revolution</a>" of 1688, when <a href="/wiki/William_III_of_England" title="William III of England">William of Orange</a> came to the throne and established the Protestant faith in England, Maryland outlawed Catholicism. This lasted until after the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American Revolutionary War</a>.  Wealthy Catholic planters built chapels on their land to practice their religion in relative secrecy.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/St._Mary%27s_City,_Maryland" title="St. Mary's City, Maryland">St. Mary's City</a> was the first (besides St. Clement's Island, where the first colonists of Maryland landed) and largest site of the original Maryland colony, and was the seat of the colonial government until 1695, when the capitol was moved to Annapolis. St Mary's is now a state-owned archaeological site and museum adjacent to St. Mary's College of Maryland.
</p><p>Most of the English colonists arrived in Maryland as <a href="/wiki/Indentured_servant" title="Indentured servant">indentured servants</a>, and had to serve a several years' term as laborers to pay for their passage.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> In the early years, the line between indentured servants and African slaves or laborers was fluid, and white and black laborers commonly lived and worked together, and formed unions. <a href="/wiki/Mixed-race" title="Mixed-race" class="mw-redirect">Mixed-race</a> children born to white mothers were considered free by the principle of <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Partus_sequitur_ventrem&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Partus sequitur ventrem (page does not exist)">partus sequitur ventrem</a></i>, by which children took the social status of their mothers, a principle of slave law that was adopted throughout the colonies, following Virginia in 1662. During the colonial era, families of <a href="/wiki/Free_people_of_color" title="Free people of color">free people of color</a> were formed most often by unions of white women and African men.<sup id="cite_ref-Heinegg_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Heinegg-42">[42]</a></sup>
</p><p>Many of the free black families migrated to Delaware, where land was cheaper.<sup id="cite_ref-Heinegg_42-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Heinegg-42">[42]</a></sup> As the flow of indentured laborers to the colony decreased with improving economic conditions in England, planters in Maryland imported thousands more slaves and racial caste lines hardened. The economy's growth and prosperity was based on slave labor, devoted first to the production of <a href="/wiki/Tobacco" title="Tobacco">tobacco</a> as the commodity crop.
</p><p>Maryland was one of the <a href="/wiki/13_colonies" title="13 colonies" class="mw-redirect">thirteen colonies</a> that revolted against British rule in the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>. On February 2, 1781, Maryland became the 13th state to approve the ratification of the <a href="/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation" title="Articles of Confederation">Articles of Confederation</a> which brought into being the United States as a united, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sovereign&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sovereign (page does not exist)">sovereign</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nation_state" title="Nation state">national state</a>. It also became the seventh state admitted to the U.S. after ratifying the new Constitution. In December 1790, Maryland donated land selected by President <a href="/wiki/George_Washington" title="George Washington">George Washington</a> to the federal government for the creation of the new national capital of <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> The land was provided from <a href="/wiki/Montgomery_County,_Maryland" title="Montgomery County, Maryland">Montgomery</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prince_George%27s_County,_Maryland" title="Prince George's County, Maryland">Prince George's</a> counties, as well as from <a href="/wiki/Fairfax_County,_Virginia" title="Fairfax County, Virginia">Fairfax County</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alexandria,_Virginia&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alexandria, Virginia (page does not exist)">Alexandria</a> in <a href="/wiki/Virginia" title="Virginia">Virginia</a>; however, the land donated by Virginia was later returned to that state by the <a href="/wiki/District_of_Columbia_retrocession" title="District of Columbia retrocession">District of Columbia retrocession</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="19th_century">19th century</span></h3>
<p>During the <a href="/wiki/War_of_1812" title="War of 1812">War of 1812</a>, the British military attempted to capture the port of Baltimore, which was protected by <a href="/wiki/Fort_McHenry" title="Fort McHenry">Fort McHenry</a>. It was during this bombardment that <a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Star_Spangled_Banner&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Star Spangled Banner (page does not exist)">the Star Spangled Banner</a> was written by <a href="/wiki/Francis_Scott_Key" title="Francis Scott Key">Francis Scott Key</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_and_Ohio_Railroad" title="Baltimore and Ohio Railroad">Baltimore and Ohio Railroad</a> (B&amp;O) was the first chartered railroad in the United States, and it opened its first section of track for regular operation in 1830, between Baltimore and Ellicott City.<sup id="cite_ref-Dilts_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Dilts-43">[43]</a></sup> In 1852 it became the first rail line to reach the <a href="/wiki/Ohio_River" title="Ohio River">Ohio River</a> from the eastern seaboard.<sup id="cite_ref-Stover_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stover-44">[44]</a></sup> Baltimore's seaport and good railroad connections fostered substantial growth during the <a href="/wiki/Industrial_Revolution" title="Industrial Revolution">Industrial Revolution</a> of the 19th century. Many manufacturing businesses were established in Baltimore and the surrounding area after the Civil War.
</p><p>Influenced by a changing economy, revolutionary ideals, and preaching by Methodist and Quaker ministers, numerous planters in Maryland freed their slaves in the twenty years after the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">Revolutionary War</a>. This was a pattern across the Upper South, in which the free black population increased markedly from less than 1% before the war to 14% by 1810.<sup id="cite_ref-Kolchin_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kolchin-45">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Civil_War">Civil War</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Antietam.png" title="File:Battle of Antietam.png">File:Battle of Antietam.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Antietam" title="Battle of Antietam">Battle of Antietam</a> on September 17, 1862&#160;— the single bloodiest day of the <a href="/wiki/American_Civil_War" title="American Civil War">Civil War</a> and all of American military history, with nearly 23,000 casualties.</div></div></div>
<p>By 1860 Maryland's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Free_black&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Free black (page does not exist)">free black</a> population comprised 49% of the total of African Americans in the state.<sup id="cite_ref-Kolchin_45-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kolchin-45">[45]</a></sup>  This contributed to the state's remaining loyal to the Union during the Civil War. In addition, Governor <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Holliday_Hicks" title="Thomas Holliday Hicks">Thomas Holliday Hicks</a> temporarily suspended the state legislature, and President <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln" title="Abraham Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a> had a number of its pro-slavery politicians, called "<a href="/wiki/Fire_eaters" title="Fire eaters" class="mw-redirect">fire eaters</a>," arrested prior to its reconvening. Lincoln ordered U.S. troops to place artillery on <a href="/w/index.php?title=Federal_Hill,_Baltimore,_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Federal Hill, Baltimore, Maryland (page does not exist)">Federal Hill</a> to threaten the city of Baltimore, and helped ensure the election of a new pro-union governor and legislature. Lincoln ordered certain pro-South members of the state legislature and other prominent men jailed at <a href="/wiki/Fort_McHenry" title="Fort McHenry">Fort McHenry</a>, including the Mayor of Baltimore, <a href="/wiki/George_William_Brown" title="George William Brown">George William Brown</a>. The grandson of <a href="/wiki/Francis_Scott_Key" title="Francis Scott Key">Francis Scott Key</a> was included in those jailed. Historians continue to debate the constitutionality of these actions taken during the crisis of wartime. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thomas_Viaduct&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thomas Viaduct (page does not exist)">Thomas Viaduct</a>, which crosses the <a href="/wiki/Patapsco_River" title="Patapsco River">Patapsco River</a> on the B&amp;O Railroad, was considered so strategically important that Union troops were assigned to guard it throughout the entirety of the war.
</p><p>In April 1861, Federal regular military units and state militia regiments arrived in Baltimore at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=President_Street_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="President Street Station (page does not exist)">President Street Station</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia,_Wilmington_and_Baltimore_Railroad" title="Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad">Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad</a>, located east of the "Basin" (Inner Harbor). The troops, headed for Washington, D.C., marched through Baltimore towards the B&amp;O <a href="/w/index.php?title=Camden_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Camden Station (page does not exist)">Camden Station</a> to continue their journey, and along the way they were attacked by an unruly mob. The incident, later known as the <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_riot_of_1861" title="Baltimore riot of 1861">Baltimore riot of 1861</a>, was the first bloodshed in the Civil War. Four soldiers and twelve civilians were killed in the riot.
</p><p>Lincoln promised to avoid having more Northern defenders march through Baltimore while getting to areas to protect the acutely endangered Federal Capital. This forced the majority of forces traveling to reinforce the National Capital to take a slow route by boat which Massachusetts militia Gen. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Benjamin_Franklin_Butler_(politician)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Benjamin Franklin Butler (politician) (page does not exist)">Benjamin F. Butler</a> (1818–1893) did several days later after hearing of the bloody reception in Baltimore by commandeering the P. W. &amp; B. Railroad ferryboat "Harriet Lane"  at the <a href="/wiki/Susquehanna_River" title="Susquehanna River">Susquehanna River</a> crossing between <a href="/wiki/Perryville,_Maryland" title="Perryville, Maryland">Perryville</a> in <a href="/wiki/Cecil_County,_Maryland" title="Cecil County, Maryland">Cecil County</a> to <a href="/wiki/Havre_de_Grace,_Maryland" title="Havre de Grace, Maryland">Havre de Grace</a> in <a href="/wiki/Harford_County,_Maryland" title="Harford County, Maryland">Harford County</a>. Avoiding the riotous city, he steamed down the <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay" title="Chesapeake Bay">Chesapeake Bay</a> to anchor at night off the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Naval_Academy" title="United States Naval Academy">Naval Academy</a> at Severn Point in <a href="/wiki/Annapolis,_Maryland" title="Annapolis, Maryland">Annapolis</a> and landing his troops of Massachusetts, New York and Rhode Island militia over the protests of Governor <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Holliday_Hicks" title="Thomas Holliday Hicks">Thomas Holliday Hicks</a> (1798–1865) after pulling the old Navy training ship frigate  <a href="/wiki/USS_Constitution" title="USS Constitution">USS Constitution</a> ("Old Ironsides") further off the shore so that southern sympathizers couldn't attack it. Then recruiting some railroad workers and boilermakers among his soldiers, they rescued a small yard locomotive in the trainyards and pushed up the Annapolis Line of the B&amp;O Railroad to Relay Junction near Ellicott City, where it joined the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Old_Main_Line_Subdivision&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Old Main Line Subdivision (page does not exist)">Main Line</a> going west to <a href="/wiki/Harpers_Ferry,_West_Virginia" title="Harpers Ferry, West Virginia">Harpers Ferry, West Virginia</a> or south to Washington. The Northern regiments shortly arrived in the station by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Capitol" title="United States Capitol">U.S. Capitol</a> and camped that evening in the Rotunda under the still un-completed dome under construction tending to their wounded. An additional unit was sent up <a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennsylvania_Avenue_National_Historic_Site&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennsylvania Avenue National Historic Site (page does not exist)">Pennsylvania Avenue</a> to reinforce the <a href="/wiki/White_House" title="White House">White House</a> where the President awaited with joy and relief.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Bloodylane.JPG" title="File:Bloodylane.JPG">File:Bloodylane.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Antietam_National_Battlefield&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antietam National Battlefield (page does not exist)">Antietam National Battlefield</a> today</div></div></div>
<p>Of the 115,000 men from Maryland who joined the military during the Civil War, 85,000, or 77%, joined the <a href="/wiki/Union_army" title="Union army" class="mw-redirect">Union army</a>, while the remainder joined the <a href="/wiki/Confederate_Army" title="Confederate Army" class="mw-redirect">Confederate Army</a>. To help ensure Maryland's inclusion in the <a href="/wiki/Union_(American_Civil_War)" title="Union (American Civil War)">Union</a>, President Lincoln suspended several civil liberties, including the writ of <i>habeas corpus.</i> This suspension was later deemed illegal by Chief Justice <a href="/wiki/Roger_Taney" title="Roger Taney" class="mw-redirect">Roger Taney</a> of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Supreme_Court" title="United States Supreme Court" class="mw-redirect">United States Supreme Court</a>, a Maryland native.
</p><p>The largest and most significant battle fought in the state was the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Antietam" title="Battle of Antietam">Battle of Antietam</a>, fought on September 17, 1862, near <a href="/wiki/Sharpsburg,_Maryland" title="Sharpsburg, Maryland">Sharpsburg</a>. Although a tactical draw, the Battle of Antietam was considered a strategic Union victory and a <a href="/wiki/Turning_point_of_the_American_Civil_War" title="Turning point of the American Civil War">turning point</a> of the war.
</p><p>Because Maryland remained in the Union, it was exempted from the abolition provisions of the <a href="/wiki/Emancipation_Proclamation" title="Emancipation Proclamation">Emancipation Proclamation</a> of 1863, which applied only to states in rebellion. In 1864 the state held a <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_convention_(political_meeting)" title="Constitutional convention (political meeting)">constitutional convention</a> that culminated in the passage of a new state constitution. Article 24 of that document <a href="/w/index.php?title=Abolitionism_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Abolitionism in the United States (page does not exist)">abolished</a> slavery. In 1867, following passage of constitutional amendments that granted voting rights to <a href="/wiki/Freedmen" title="Freedmen" class="mw-redirect">freedmen</a>, the state extended suffrage to non-white males.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="After_the_war">After the war</span></h4>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States_Democratic_Party&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of the United States Democratic Party (page does not exist)">Democratic Party</a> rapidly regained power in the state and replaced <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_United_States_Republican_Party&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of the United States Republican Party (page does not exist)">Republicans</a> who had ruled during the war.  Support for the Constitution of 1864 ended, and Democrats replaced it with the <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Constitution_of_1867" title="Maryland Constitution of 1867" class="mw-redirect">Maryland Constitution of 1867</a>.
</p><p>As the industrial revolution swept across the northeast and midwestern United States, Baltimore continued to expand and prosper. Baltimore businessmen, including <a href="/wiki/Johns_Hopkins" title="Johns Hopkins">Johns Hopkins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Enoch_Pratt" title="Enoch Pratt">Enoch Pratt</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Peabody" title="George Peabody">George Peabody</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Walters" title="Henry Walters">Henry Walters</a> founded notable educational, health care, and cultural institutions in the city, which bear their names, including a university, library, music school and art museum.
</p><p>Cumberland was Maryland's second largest city in the 19th century, with ample nearby supplies of coal, iron ore and timber. These resources, along with railroads, the <a href="/wiki/National_Road" title="National Road">National Road</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_and_Ohio_Canal" title="Chesapeake and Ohio Canal">Chesapeake and Ohio Canal</a>, fostered its growth.<sup id="cite_ref-WDL_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WDL-46">[46]</a></sup> The city was a major manufacturing center, with industries in glass, breweries, fabrics and tinplate.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="20th_century">20th century</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Progressive_Era" title="Progressive Era">Progressive Era</a> of the late 19th and early 20th centuries brought reforms in the political arena and in working conditions for Maryland's labor force. In a series of laws passed between 1892 and 1908, reformers worked for standard state-issued ballots (rather than those distributed and pre-marked by the parties); obtained closed voting booths to prevent party workers from "assisting" voters; initiated <a href="/wiki/Primary_election" title="Primary election">primary elections</a> to keep party bosses from selecting candidates; and had candidates listed without party symbols, which discouraged the <a href="/wiki/Illiterate" title="Illiterate" class="mw-redirect">illiterate</a> from participating.
</p><p>In 1902, the state regulated conditions in <a href="/wiki/Mining" title="Mining">mines</a>; outlawed <a href="/w/index.php?title=Child_labor&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Child labor (page does not exist)">child laborers</a> under the age of 12; mandated compulsory school attendance; and enacted the nation's first <a href="/wiki/Workers%27_compensation" title="Workers' compensation">workers' compensation</a> law. The workers' compensation law was overturned in the courts, but was redrafted and finally enacted in 1910.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Great_Baltimore_Fire" title="Great Baltimore Fire">Great Baltimore Fire</a> of February 8, 1904 was a momentous event for Maryland's largest city and the state as a whole. More than 1,231 <a href="/wiki/Firefighter" title="Firefighter">firefighters</a>, some coming from cities as far away as <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York</a>, worked to bring the blaze under control. The fire burned over 30 hours, destroying 1,526 buildings and spanning 70 city blocks.
</p><p>The nation's <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_War_I&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World War I (page does not exist)">entry into World War I</a> in 1917 brought changes to Maryland. New military bases, such as Camp Meade (now <a href="/wiki/Fort_George_G._Meade" title="Fort George G. Meade">Fort Meade</a>) and the <a href="/wiki/Aberdeen_Proving_Ground" title="Aberdeen Proving Ground">Aberdeen Proving Ground</a> were established in 1917, and the <a href="/wiki/Edgewood_Arsenal" title="Edgewood Arsenal" class="mw-redirect">Edgewood Arsenal</a> was founded the following year. Other existing facilities, including <a href="/wiki/Fort_McHenry" title="Fort McHenry">Fort McHenry</a>, were greatly expanded.
</p><p>Maryland's urban and rural communities had different experiences during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Depression&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Depression (page does not exist)">Great Depression</a>. In 1932 the "<a href="/wiki/Bonus_Army" title="Bonus Army">Bonus Army</a>" marched through the state on its way to Washington, D.C. In addition to the nationwide <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Deal&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Deal (page does not exist)">New Deal</a> reforms of President <a href="/wiki/Franklin_Roosevelt" title="Franklin Roosevelt" class="mw-redirect">Franklin Roosevelt</a>, which put men to work building roads and park facilities, Maryland also took steps to weather the hard times. For instance, in 1937 the state instituted its first ever <a href="/wiki/Income_tax" title="Income tax">income tax</a> to generate revenue for schools and welfare.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>Baltimore was a major war production center during <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>. The biggest operations were <a href="/wiki/Bethlehem_Steel" title="Bethlehem Steel">Bethlehem Steel</a>'s Fairfield Yard, which built <a href="/wiki/Liberty_ship" title="Liberty ship">Liberty ships</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Glenn_L._Martin_Company" title="Glenn L. Martin Company">Glenn Martin</a>, an aircraft manufacturer.
</p><p>Following World War II, Maryland experienced growth in the suburbs, particularly in the region surrounding Baltimore and Washington, D.C. Agricultural tracts gave way to residential communities such as <a href="/wiki/Columbia,_Maryland" title="Columbia, Maryland">Columbia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Montgomery_Village,_Maryland" title="Montgomery Village, Maryland">Montgomery Village</a>. Concurrently the <a href="/wiki/Interstate_Highway_System" title="Interstate Highway System">Interstate Highway System</a> was built throughout the state, most notably <a href="/w/index.php?title=Interstate_95_in_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Interstate 95 in Maryland (page does not exist)">I-95</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Interstate_495_(Capital_Beltway)" title="Interstate 495 (Capital Beltway)">Capital Beltway</a>, permanently altering the landscape and travel patterns. In 1952, the eastern and western halves of Maryland were linked for the first time by the long <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay_Bridge" title="Chesapeake Bay Bridge">Chesapeake Bay Bridge</a>, which replaced a nearby <a href="/wiki/Ferry" title="Ferry">ferry</a> service.<sup id="cite_ref-baybridge.com-history_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-baybridge.com-history-47">[47]</a></sup> This bridge (and its later, parallel span) increased tourist traffic to Ocean City, which experienced a building boom. Soon after, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore_Harbor_Tunnel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore Harbor Tunnel (page does not exist)">Baltimore Harbor Tunnel</a> allowed long-distance interstate motorists to bypass downtown Baltimore, while the earlier <a href="/wiki/Harry_W._Nice_Memorial_Bridge" title="Harry W. Nice Memorial Bridge" class="mw-redirect">Harry W. Nice Memorial Bridge</a> allowed them to bypass Washington, D.C.
</p><p>In a pattern similar to that of other U.S. cities, heavy manufacturing declined in Baltimore after the war. Large-scale, mechanized poultry farms became prevalent on the lower Eastern Shore, along with irrigated vegetable farming. In Southern Maryland tobacco farming had nearly vanished by the century's end, due to suburban housing development and a state tobacco incentive buy-out program. Industrial, railroad, and coal mining jobs in the four westernmost counties declined.
</p><p>Baltimore initiated urban renewal projects beginning in the 1960s with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Charles_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Charles Center (page does not exist)">Charles Center</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_World_Trade_Center" title="Baltimore World Trade Center">Baltimore World Trade Center</a>. In 1980, the opening of <a href="/wiki/Harborplace" title="Harborplace">Harborplace</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_Aquarium" title="Baltimore Aquarium" class="mw-redirect">Baltimore Aquarium</a> made the city a significant tourist destination. The popular <a href="/wiki/Camden_Yards" title="Camden Yards" class="mw-redirect">Camden Yards</a> baseball stadium opened in 1992 in the downtown area.
</p><p>At the end of the century, Maryland joined with neighboring states to improve the health of the Chesapeake Bay. The bay's aquatic life and seafood industry have been threatened by suburban and waterfront residential development, as well as by fertilizer and livestock waste entering the bay in <a href="/wiki/Stormwater" title="Stormwater">stormwater</a> runoff, especially from the upper Susquehanna River in Pennsylvania.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:US_Census_population&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:US Census population (page does not exist)">Template:US Census population</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maryland_population_map.png" title="File:Maryland population map.png">File:Maryland population map.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A map of Maryland's population distribution</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau" title="United States Census Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a> estimates that the population of Maryland was 5,928,814 on July 1, 2013, a 2.7% increase since the <a href="/w/index.php?title=2010_United_States_Census&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="2010 United States Census (page does not exist)">2010 United States Census</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-PopEstUS_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PopEstUS-50">[50]</a></sup>
