</p><p>As of 2006, Maryland has an estimated population of 5,615,727, which is an increase of 26,128, or 0.5 percent, from the prior year and an increase of 319,221, or 6.0 percent, since the year 2000. This includes a natural increase since the last census of 189,158 people (that is 464,251 births minus 275,093 deaths) and an increase due to net migration of 116,713 people into the state. <a href="/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States" title="Immigration to the United States">Immigration</a> from outside the United States resulted in a net increase of 129,730 people, and migration within the country produced a net loss of 13,017 people.
</p><p>In 2006, 645,744 were counted as foreign born, which represents mainly people from Latin America and Asia. About 4.0 percent are undocumented (illegal) immigrants.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup> Maryland also has a large Korean American population.<sup id="cite_ref-52" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-52">[52]</a></sup> In fact, 1.7 percent are Korean, while as a whole, almost 6.0 percent are Asian.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>Most of the population of Maryland lives in the central region of the state, in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore_Metropolitan_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore Metropolitan Area (page does not exist)">Baltimore Metropolitan Area</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Washington_Metropolitan_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Washington Metropolitan Area (page does not exist)">Washington Metropolitan Area</a>, both of which are part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore-Washington_Metropolitan_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore-Washington Metropolitan Area (page does not exist)">Baltimore-Washington Metropolitan Area</a>. The Eastern Shore is less populous and more rural, as are the counties of western and southern Maryland.
</p><p>The two <a href="/wiki/Western_Maryland" title="Western Maryland">westernmost</a> counties of Maryland, <a href="/wiki/Allegany_County,_Maryland" title="Allegany County, Maryland">Allegany</a> and <a href="/wiki/Garrett_County,_Maryland" title="Garrett County, Maryland">Garrett</a>, are mountainous and sparsely populated, resembling West Virginia more than they do the rest of Maryland.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Center_of_population" title="Center of population">center of population</a> of Maryland is located on the county line between <a href="/wiki/Anne_Arundel_County,_Maryland" title="Anne Arundel County, Maryland">Anne Arundel County</a> and <a href="/wiki/Howard_County,_Maryland" title="Howard County, Maryland">Howard County</a>, in the <a href="/wiki/Unincorporated_area" title="Unincorporated area">unincorporated community</a> of <a href="/wiki/Jessup,_Maryland" title="Jessup, Maryland">Jessup</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_maryland_counties.jpg" title="File:Map of maryland counties.jpg">File:Map of maryland counties.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/List_of_counties_in_Maryland" title="List of counties in Maryland">Maryland's counties</a></div></div></div>
<p>The majority of Maryland's population is concentrated in the cities and suburbs surrounding <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, as well as in and around Maryland's most populous city, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore (page does not exist)">Baltimore</a>. Historically, these and many other Maryland cities developed along the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Fall_Line&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Fall Line (page does not exist)">Fall Line</a>, the line along which rivers, brooks, and streams are interrupted by rapids and/or waterfalls. Maryland's capital city, <a href="/wiki/Annapolis,_Maryland" title="Annapolis, Maryland">Annapolis</a>, is one exception to this pattern, since it lies along the banks of the <a href="/wiki/Severn_River_(Maryland)" title="Severn River (Maryland)">Severn River</a>, close to where it empties into the <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay" title="Chesapeake Bay">Chesapeake Bay</a>.
</p><p>The other population centers of Maryland include suburban areas of <a href="/wiki/Columbia,_Maryland" title="Columbia, Maryland">Columbia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ellicott_City,_Maryland" title="Ellicott City, Maryland">Ellicott City</a> in <a href="/wiki/Howard_County,_Maryland" title="Howard County, Maryland">Howard County</a>; <a href="/wiki/Silver_Spring,_Maryland" title="Silver Spring, Maryland">Silver Spring</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rockville,_Maryland" title="Rockville, Maryland">Rockville</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Gaithersburg,_Maryland" title="Gaithersburg, Maryland">Gaithersburg</a> in <a href="/wiki/Montgomery_County,_Maryland" title="Montgomery County, Maryland">Montgomery County</a>; <a href="/wiki/Laurel,_Maryland" title="Laurel, Maryland">Laurel</a>, <a href="/wiki/College_Park,_Maryland" title="College Park, Maryland">College Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Greenbelt,_Maryland" title="Greenbelt, Maryland">Greenbelt</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hyattsville,_Maryland" title="Hyattsville, Maryland">Hyattsville</a>, <a href="/wiki/Landover,_Maryland" title="Landover, Maryland">Landover</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clinton,_Maryland" title="Clinton, Maryland">Clinton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bowie,_Maryland" title="Bowie, Maryland">Bowie</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Greater_Upper_Marlboro,_Maryland" title="Greater Upper Marlboro, Maryland">Upper Marlboro</a> in <a href="/wiki/Prince_George%27s_County,_Maryland" title="Prince George's County, Maryland">Prince George's County</a>; <a href="/wiki/Frederick,_Maryland" title="Frederick, Maryland">Frederick</a> in <a href="/wiki/Frederick_County,_Maryland" title="Frederick County, Maryland">Frederick County</a>; <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hagerstown,_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hagerstown, Maryland (page does not exist)">Hagerstown</a> in <a href="/wiki/Washington_County,_Maryland" title="Washington County, Maryland">Washington County</a>; <a href="/wiki/Waldorf,_Maryland" title="Waldorf, Maryland">Waldorf</a> in <a href="/wiki/Charles_County,_Maryland" title="Charles County, Maryland">Charles County</a>; <a href="/wiki/Pikesville,_Maryland" title="Pikesville, Maryland">Pikesville</a>, <a href="/wiki/Essex,_Maryland" title="Essex, Maryland">Essex</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Towson,_Maryland" title="Towson, Maryland">Towson</a> in <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_County,_Maryland" title="Baltimore County, Maryland">Baltimore County</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Glen_Burnie,_Maryland" title="Glen Burnie, Maryland">Glen Burnie</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hanover,_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hanover, Maryland (page does not exist)">Hanover</a> in <a href="/wiki/Anne_Arundel_County,_Maryland" title="Anne Arundel County, Maryland">Anne Arundel</a>.
</p><p>The eastern, southern, and western portions of the state tend to be more rural, although they are dotted with cities of regional importance, such as <a href="/wiki/Ocean_City,_Maryland" title="Ocean City, Maryland">Ocean City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Princess_Anne,_Maryland" title="Princess Anne, Maryland">Princess Anne</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Salisbury,_Maryland" title="Salisbury, Maryland">Salisbury</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Shore_of_Maryland" title="Eastern Shore of Maryland">Eastern Shore</a>; <a href="/wiki/Lexington_Park,_Maryland" title="Lexington Park, Maryland">Lexington Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prince_Frederick,_Maryland" title="Prince Frederick, Maryland">Prince Frederick</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Waldorf,_Maryland" title="Waldorf, Maryland">Waldorf</a> in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Maryland" title="Southern Maryland">Southern Maryland</a>; and <a href="/wiki/Cumberland,_Maryland" title="Cumberland, Maryland">Cumberland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frostburg,_Maryland" title="Frostburg, Maryland">Frostburg</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hancock,_Maryland" title="Hancock, Maryland">Hancock</a> in <a href="/wiki/Western_Maryland" title="Western Maryland">Western Maryland</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Regions_of_Maryland_USA.gif" title="File:Regions of Maryland USA.gif">File:Regions of Maryland USA.gif</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Geographic regions of Maryland</div></div></div>
<p>Maryland's history as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Border_states_(Civil_War)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Border states (Civil War) (page does not exist)">border state</a> has led it to exhibit characteristics of both the <a href="/wiki/Northern_United_States" title="Northern United States">Northern</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southern_United_States" title="Southern United States">Southern</a> regions of the United States. Generally, rural <a href="/wiki/Western_Maryland" title="Western Maryland">Western Maryland</a> between the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Panhandle_of_West_Virginia" title="Eastern Panhandle of West Virginia">West Virginian Panhandle</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania" title="Pennsylvania">Pennsylvania</a> has an <a href="/wiki/Appalachia" title="Appalachia">Appalachian</a> culture; the <a href="/wiki/Southern_Maryland" title="Southern Maryland">Southern</a> and Eastern Shore regions of Maryland embody a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Culture_of_the_Southern_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Culture of the Southern United States (page does not exist)">Southern culture</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> while densely populated Central Maryland—radiating outward from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore (page does not exist)">Baltimore</a> and <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>—has more in common with that of the <a href="/wiki/Northeastern_United_States" title="Northeastern United States">Northeast</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> The <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="http://www.census.gov/geo/www/reg_div.txt">U.S. Census Bureau</a> designates Maryland as one of the <a href="/wiki/South_Atlantic_States" title="South Atlantic States">South Atlantic States</a>, but it is commonly associated with the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mid-Atlantic_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mid-Atlantic States (page does not exist)">Mid-Atlantic States</a> and/or <a href="/wiki/Northeastern_United_States" title="Northeastern United States">Northeastern United States</a> by other federal agencies, the media, and some residents.<sup id="cite_ref-LOC_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-LOC-57">[57]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-EPA_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EPA-58">[58]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FBI_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FBI-59">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-amtrak_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-amtrak-60">[60]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-princeton_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-princeton-61">[61]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Racial_and_ethnic_makeup">Racial and ethnic makeup</span></h3>
<p>According to a 2012 estimate,<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> the racial composition of the state was:
</p>
<ul>
<li> 60.8% <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White American (page does not exist)">White American</a> (53.9% <a href="/w/index.php?title=Non-Hispanic_White&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Non-Hispanic White (page does not exist)">non-Hispanic White</a>, 6.9% <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_Hispanic&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White Hispanic (page does not exist)">White Hispanic</a>)
</li>
<li> 30.0% <a href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American">Black</a> or African American
</li>
<li> 0.5% <a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">American Indian</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alaska_Native&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alaska Native (page does not exist)">Alaska Native</a>
</li>
<li> 6.0% <a href="/wiki/Asian_American" title="Asian American">Asian American</a>
</li>
<li> 0.1% <a href="/wiki/Native_Hawaiian" title="Native Hawaiian" class="mw-redirect">Native Hawaiian</a> and Other <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islander" title="Pacific Islander">Pacific Islander</a>
</li>
<li> 2.5% <a href="/w/index.php?title=Multiracial_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Multiracial American (page does not exist)">Multiracial American</a>
</li>
</ul>
<p><a href="/wiki/Hispanic_and_Latino_Americans" title="Hispanic and Latino Americans">Hispanics</a> and Latinos of any race make up 8.7% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-PopUS_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PopUS-63">[63]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable sortable collapsible" style="font-size: 90%;">
<caption> <b>Maryland Racial Breakdown of Population</b>
</caption>
<tr>
<th> Racial composition  </th>
<th> 1990<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> </th>
<th> 2000<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup></th>
<th> 2010<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=White_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="White American (page does not exist)">White</a> </td>
<td> 71.0% </td>
<td> 64.0% </td>
<td> 58.2%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/African_American" title="African American">Black</a> </td>
<td> 24.9% </td>
<td> 27.9% </td>
<td> 29.4%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Asian_American" title="Asian American">Asian</a> </td>
<td> 2.9% </td>
<td> 4.0% </td>
<td> 5.5%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">Native</a> </td>
<td> 0.3% </td>
<td> 0.3% </td>
<td> 0.3%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Native_Hawaiian" title="Native Hawaiian" class="mw-redirect">Native Hawaiian</a> and <br /><a href="/wiki/Pacific_Islander" title="Pacific Islander">other Pacific Islander</a> </td>
<td> - </td>
<td> - </td>
<td> 0.1%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/wiki/Race_and_ethnicity_in_the_United_States_Census" title="Race and ethnicity in the United States Census">Other race</a> </td>
<td> 0.9% </td>
<td> 1.8% </td>
<td> 3.6%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Multiracial_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Multiracial American (page does not exist)">Two or more races</a> </td>
<td> - </td>
<td> 2.0% </td>
<td> 2.9%
</td></tr></table>
<p>In 1970, the Census Bureau reported Maryland's population as 17.8 percent African-American and 80.4 percent non-Hispanic White.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>As of 2011, 58.0 percent of Maryland's population younger than age 1 were minorities(note: children born to white Hispanics are counted as minority group).<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/African-Americans" title="African-Americans" class="mw-redirect">African-Americans</a> form a sizable portion of the state's population&#160;– nearly 30 percent in 2010<sup id="cite_ref-PopUS_63-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-PopUS-63">[63]</a></sup>&#160;– including immigrants from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nigerian_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nigerian American (page does not exist)">Nigeria</a>, particularly the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Igbo_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Igbo American (page does not exist)">Igbo</a> tribe.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> Although populous in most of the state, large concentrations of African-American population can be found in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore,_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore, Maryland (page does not exist)">Baltimore City</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prince_George%27s_County,_Maryland" title="Prince George's County, Maryland">Prince George's County</a>, <a href="/wiki/Charles_County,_Maryland" title="Charles County, Maryland">Charles County</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Randallstown&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Randallstown (page does not exist)">Randallstown</a>, and the southern Eastern Shore.
</p><p>Most of the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Shore_of_Maryland" title="Eastern Shore of Maryland">Eastern Shore</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southern_Maryland" title="Southern Maryland">Southern Maryland</a> are populated by Marylanders of <a href="/wiki/British_American" title="British American">British</a> ancestry, with the Eastern Shore traditionally Methodist and the southern counties Catholic. Western and northern Maryland have large <a href="/wiki/German-American" title="German-American" class="mw-redirect">German-American</a> populations. <a href="/wiki/Italians" title="Italians">Italians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Poles" title="Poles">Poles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Czechs" title="Czechs">Czechs</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Greeks" title="Greeks">Greeks</a> are centered mostly in the large city of Baltimore.  Hispanics are numerous in <a href="/wiki/Hyattsville,_Maryland" title="Hyattsville, Maryland">Hyattsville</a>/<a href="/wiki/Langley_Park,_Maryland" title="Langley Park, Maryland">Langley Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Wheaton,_Maryland" title="Wheaton, Maryland">Wheaton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bladensburg,_Maryland" title="Bladensburg, Maryland">Bladensburg</a>, <a href="/wiki/Riverdale_Park,_Maryland" title="Riverdale Park, Maryland">Riverdale Park</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gaithersburg,_Maryland" title="Gaithersburg, Maryland">Gaithersburg</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Highlandtown,_Baltimore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Highlandtown, Baltimore (page does not exist)">Highlandtown</a> in East Baltimore.  <a href="/w/index.php?title=Salvadoran_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Salvadoran American (page does not exist)">Salvadorans</a> are the largest Hispanic group in Maryland. Other Hispanic groups with significant populations in the state include <a href="/wiki/Mexican_American" title="Mexican American">Mexicans</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Puerto_Rican_American&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Puerto Rican American (page does not exist)">Puerto Ricans</a>. Though the Salvadoran population is more concentrated in the area around Washington, DC, and the Puerto Rican population is more concentrated in the Baltimore area, all other major Hispanic groups in the state are evenly dispersed between these two areas. Maryland has one of the most diverse Hispanic populations in the country, with significant populations from various <a href="/w/index.php?title=Spanish_Caribbean&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Spanish Caribbean (page does not exist)">Caribbean</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_America" title="Central America">Central American</a> nations.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>Jews are numerous throughout <a href="/wiki/Montgomery_County,_Maryland" title="Montgomery County, Maryland">Montgomery County</a> and in <a href="/wiki/Pikesville,_Maryland" title="Pikesville, Maryland">Pikesville</a> and <a href="/wiki/Owings_Mills" title="Owings Mills" class="mw-redirect">Owings Mills</a> northwest of Baltimore. Asian Americans are concentrated in the suburban counties surrounding Washington, D.C., especially evident by a <a href="/wiki/Korean_American" title="Korean American">Korean American</a> and <a href="/wiki/Taiwanese_American" title="Taiwanese American">Taiwanese American</a> community in <a href="/wiki/Rockville,_Maryland" title="Rockville, Maryland">Rockville</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Filipino_American" title="Filipino American">Filipino American</a> community in <a href="/wiki/Fort_Washington,_Maryland" title="Fort Washington, Maryland">Fort Washington</a>. There are also numerous <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indian_Americans&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indian Americans (page does not exist)">Indian Americans</a> living across the state, especially in central Maryland. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Amish&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Amish (page does not exist)">Amish</a>/<a href="/wiki/Mennonite" title="Mennonite">Mennonite</a> communities are found in <a href="/wiki/St._Mary%27s_County,_Maryland" title="St. Mary's County, Maryland">St. Mary's</a>, <a href="/wiki/Garrett_County,_Maryland" title="Garrett County, Maryland">Garrett</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Washington_County,_Maryland" title="Washington County, Maryland">Washington</a> counties.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p><p>Maryland has the fifth largest proportions of racial minorities in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to The Williams Institute's analysis of the 2010 U.S. Census, 12,538 same-sex couples are living in Maryland, representing 5.8 same-sex couples per 1,000 households.<sup id="cite_ref-freedomtomarry.org_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-freedomtomarry.org-72">[72]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Largest_cities.2C_towns_and_places">Largest cities, towns and places</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Largest_cities_of_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Largest cities of Maryland (page does not exist)">Template:Largest cities of Maryland</a>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:BasilicaExterior.jpg" title="File:BasilicaExterior.jpg">File:BasilicaExterior.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore_Basilica&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore Basilica (page does not exist)">Baltimore Basilica</a> was the first <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholic" title="Roman Catholic" class="mw-redirect">Roman Catholic</a> <a href="/wiki/Cathedral" title="Cathedral">cathedral</a> built in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States (page does not exist)">United States</a>. It is considered to be the masterpiece of architect <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Henry_Latrobe" title="Benjamin Henry Latrobe">Benjamin Henry Latrobe</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Maryland was founded for the purpose of providing religious toleration of England's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Catholic_Church&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Catholic Church (page does not exist)">Roman Catholic</a> minority. Nevertheless, Parliament later reversed that policy and discouraged the practice of Catholicism in Maryland. Due to immigration patterns, Catholics have not continuously been a majority in Maryland since early Colonial times. Nonetheless, Catholicism is the largest single denomination in Maryland.
</p><p>As of the year 2010, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Association_of_Religion_Data_Archives&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Association of Religion Data Archives (page does not exist)">Association of Religion Data Archives</a> (ARDA) <sup id="cite_ref-www.thearda.com_73-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www.thearda.com-73">[73]</a></sup> reported that the largest religious groups in Maryland are: The <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a>, non-denominational <a href="/w/index.php?title=Evangelical_Protestant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Evangelical Protestant (page does not exist)">Evangelical Protestant</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/United_Methodist_Church" title="United Methodist Church">United Methodist Church</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a> has the highest number of adherents in Maryland (at 837,338), followed by non-denominational <a href="/w/index.php?title=Evangelical_Protestant&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Evangelical Protestant (page does not exist)">Evangelical Protestants</a> with 298,921 members reported. Judaism is the largest non-Christian religion with 241,000 adherents, or 4.3 percent of the total population.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> The present religious composition of the state is shown below:<sup id="cite_ref-www.thearda.com_73-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-www.thearda.com-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p>
<table class="wikitable">

<tr>
<th colspan="6">
<p><span style="font-size:125%;"><b>Religions in Maryland</b>
</p>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<th colspan="4">
<p>Christian
</p>
</th>
<th colspan="2">
<p>Other
</p>
</th></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism" title="Roman Catholicism" class="mw-redirect">Roman Catholic</a>
</td>
<td>14.5%
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td><a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Jewish</a>
</td>
<td>1.4%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Baptist&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baptist (page does not exist)">Baptist</a>
</td>
<td>5.2%
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td><a href="/w/index.php?title=Islam&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Islam (page does not exist)">Muslim</a>
</td>
<td>0.6%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>Other Religions
</td>
<td>3.5%
</td></tr>
<tr>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td>
<td>
</td></tr></table>
<p>Despite the Protestant majority, Maryland has been prominent in U.S. Catholic tradition, partially because it was intended by <a href="/wiki/George_Calvert" title="George Calvert" class="mw-redirect">George Calvert</a> as a haven for English Catholics. Baltimore was the seat of the first Catholic bishop in the U.S. (1789), and <a href="/wiki/Emmitsburg" title="Emmitsburg" class="mw-redirect">Emmitsburg</a> was the home and burial place of the first American-born citizen to be <a href="/wiki/Canonized" title="Canonized" class="mw-redirect">canonized</a>, <a href="/wiki/St._Elizabeth_Ann_Seton" title="St. Elizabeth Ann Seton" class="mw-redirect">St. Elizabeth Ann Seton</a>. <a href="/wiki/Georgetown_University" title="Georgetown University">Georgetown University</a>, the first Catholic University, was founded in 1789 in what was then part of Maryland.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Basilica_of_the_National_Shrine_of_the_Assumption_of_the_Virgin_Mary" title="Basilica of the National Shrine of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary" class="mw-redirect">Basilica of the National Shrine of the Assumption of the Virgin Mary</a> in Baltimore was the first Roman Catholic cathedral built in the United States, and the <a href="/wiki/Archbishop_of_Baltimore" title="Archbishop of Baltimore" class="mw-redirect">Archbishop of Baltimore</a> is, albeit without formal primacy, the United States' quasi-<a href="/wiki/Primate_(bishop)" title="Primate (bishop)">primate</a>, and often a Cardinal.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventist Church</a>'s World Headquarters is located in <a href="/wiki/Silver_Spring,_Maryland" title="Silver Spring, Maryland">Silver Spring</a>, just outside the District of Columbia.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Baltoport.jpg" title="File:Baltoport.jpg">File:Baltoport.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Port of Baltimore</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Bureau_of_Economic_Analysis" title="Bureau of Economic Analysis">Bureau of Economic Analysis</a> estimates that Maryland's gross state product in 2012 was US$317.7 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-Gross_State_Product_MD_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gross_State_Product_MD-76">[76]</a></sup> However, Maryland has been using <a href="/w/index.php?title=Genuine_Progress_Indicator&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Genuine Progress Indicator (page does not exist)">Genuine Progress Indicator</a>, an indicator of well-being, to guide the state's development, rather than relying only on growth indicators like GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau" title="United States Census Bureau">U.S. Census Bureau</a>, Maryland households are currently the wealthiest in the country, with a 2009 median household income of $69,272<sup id="cite_ref-census1_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census1-79">[79]</a></sup> which puts it ahead of <a href="/wiki/New_Jersey" title="New Jersey">New Jersey</a> and <a href="/wiki/Connecticut" title="Connecticut">Connecticut</a>, which are second and third respectively. Two of Maryland's counties, Howard and Montgomery, are the third and tenth <a href="/w/index.php?title=Highest-income_counties_in_the_United_States&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Highest-income counties in the United States (page does not exist)">wealthiest counties in the nation</a> respectively. Also, the state's poverty rate of 7.8 percent is the lowest in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> Per capita personal income in 2006 was US$43,500, 5th in the nation.
</p><p>As of March 2012, the state's unemployment rate was 6.6 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup>
</p><p>Maryland's economic activity is strongly concentrated in the tertiary service sector, and this sector, in turn, is strongly influenced by location. One major service activity is transportation, centered on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Port_of_Baltimore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Port of Baltimore (page does not exist)">Port of Baltimore</a> and its related <a href="/w/index.php?title=Railroad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Railroad (page does not exist)">rail</a> and trucking access. The port ranked 17th in the U.S. by tonnage in 2008.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> Although the port handles a wide variety of products, the most typical imports are raw materials and bulk commodities, such as <a href="/wiki/Iron_ore" title="Iron ore">iron ore</a>, <a href="/wiki/Petroleum" title="Petroleum">petroleum</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sugar" title="Sugar">sugar</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Fertilizer" title="Fertilizer">fertilizers</a>, often distributed to the relatively close manufacturing centers of the inland <a href="/wiki/Midwest" title="Midwest" class="mw-redirect">Midwest</a> via good overland transportation. The port also receives several different brands of imported motor vehicles and is the number two auto port in the U.S.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>A second service activity takes advantage of the close location of the center of government in Washington, D.C. and emphasizes technical and administrative tasks for the defense/aerospace industry and bio-research laboratories, as well as staffing of satellite government headquarters in the suburban or exurban Baltimore/Washington area. In addition, a number of educational and medical research institutions are located in the state. In fact, the various components of The <a href="/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_University" title="Johns Hopkins University">Johns Hopkins University</a> and its medical research facilities are now the largest single employer in the Baltimore area. Altogether, <a href="/wiki/White-collar_worker" title="White-collar worker">white collar</a> technical and administrative workers comprise 25 percent of Maryland's <a href="/wiki/Labor_force" title="Labor force">labor force</a>, attributable in part to nearby Maryland being a part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Washington_Metro_Area&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Washington Metro Area (page does not exist)">Washington Metro Area</a> where the federal government office employment is relatively high.
</p><p>Maryland has a large food-production sector. A large component of this is commercial <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_freshwater_fishes_of_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of freshwater fishes of Maryland (page does not exist)">fishing</a>, centered in the Chesapeake Bay, but also including activity off the short Atlantic seacoast. The largest catches by species are the <a href="/wiki/Callinectes_sapidus" title="Callinectes sapidus">blue crab</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oysters" title="Oysters" class="mw-redirect">oysters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Striped_bass" title="Striped bass">striped bass</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Menhaden" title="Menhaden">menhaden</a>. The Bay also has overwintering waterfowl in its wildlife refuges. The waterfowl support a <a href="/wiki/Birdwatching" title="Birdwatching">tourism sector of sportsmen</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:CarrollCountyMD.jpg" title="File:CarrollCountyMD.jpg">File:CarrollCountyMD.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Agriculture is an important part of the state's economy</div></div></div>
<p>Maryland has large areas of fertile agricultural land in its coastal and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Piedmont_Plateau&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Piedmont Plateau (page does not exist)">Piedmont</a> zones, though this land use is being encroached upon by urbanization. Agriculture is oriented to dairy farming (especially in foothill and piedmont areas) for nearby large city milksheads plus specialty perishable horticulture crops, such as <a href="/wiki/Cucumber" title="Cucumber">cucumbers</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Watermelon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Watermelon (page does not exist)">watermelons</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sweet_corn" title="Sweet corn">sweet corn</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Tomato&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tomato (page does not exist)">tomatoes</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Muskmelon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Muskmelon (page does not exist)">muskmelons</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Squash_(fruit)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Squash (fruit) (page does not exist)">squash</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Peas" title="Peas" class="mw-redirect">peas</a> (Source:USDA Crop Profiles). In addition, the southern counties of the western shoreline of Chesapeake Bay are warm enough to support a <a href="/wiki/Tobacco" title="Tobacco">tobacco</a> <a href="/wiki/Cash_crop" title="Cash crop">cash crop</a> zone, which has existed since early Colonial times but declined greatly after a state government buyout in the 1990s. There is also a large automated <a href="/wiki/Chicken" title="Chicken">chicken</a>-farming sector in the state's southeastern part; <a href="/wiki/Salisbury,_Maryland" title="Salisbury, Maryland">Salisbury</a> is home to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Perdue_Farms&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Perdue Farms (page does not exist)">Perdue Farms</a>. Maryland's food-processing plants are the most significant type of manufacturing by value in the state.
</p><p>Manufacturing, while large in dollar value, is highly diversified with no sub-sector contributing over 20 percent of the total. Typical forms of manufacturing include electronics, computer equipment, and chemicals. The once mighty primary metals sub-sector, which at one time included what was then the largest steel factory in the world at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sparrows_Point&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Sparrows Point (page does not exist)">Sparrows Point</a>, still exists, but is pressed with foreign competition, <a href="/wiki/Bankruptcy" title="Bankruptcy">bankruptcies</a>, and company <a href="/wiki/Merger" title="Merger" class="mw-redirect">mergers</a>. During World War II the Glenn Martin Company (now part of <a href="/wiki/Lockheed_Martin" title="Lockheed Martin">Lockheed Martin</a>) airplane factory employed some 40,000 people.
</p><p>Mining other than construction materials is virtually limited to coal, which is located in the mountainous western part of the state. The brownstone quarries in the east, which gave Baltimore and Washington much of their characteristic architecture in the mid-19th century, were once a predominant natural resource. Historically, there used to be small gold-mining operations in Maryland, some surprisingly near Washington, but these no longer exist.
</p><p>Baltimore City is the eighth largest port in the nation, and was at the center of the February 2006 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dubai_Ports_World_controversy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dubai Ports World controversy (page does not exist)">controversy</a> over the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Dubai_Ports_World&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Dubai Ports World (page does not exist)">Dubai Ports World</a> deal because it was considered to be of such strategic importance. The state as a whole is heavily industrialized, with a booming economy and influential technology centers. Its computer industries are some of the most sophisticated in the United States, and the federal government has invested heavily in the area. Maryland is home to several large military bases and scores of high level government jobs.
</p><p>According to a study by Phoenix Marketing International, Maryland ranked No. 1 with the most millionaires per capita in 2013, with a ratio of 7.70 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> 
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Taxation">Taxation</span></h3>
<p>Maryland imposes 5 <a href="/wiki/Income_tax" title="Income tax">income tax</a> brackets, ranging from 2  to 6.25 percent of personal income.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> The city of Baltimore and Maryland's 23 counties levy local "piggyback" income taxes at rates between 1.25  and 3.2 percent of Maryland taxable income. Local officials set the rates and the revenue is returned to the local governments quarterly. The top income tax bracket of 9.45 percent is the fifth highest combined state and local income tax rates in the country, behind New York City's 11.35 percent, California’s 10.3 percent, Rhode Island’s 9.9 percent, and Vermont’s 9.5 percent.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>Maryland's state <a href="/wiki/Sales_tax" title="Sales tax">sales tax</a> is 6 percent. All real property in Maryland is subject to the <a href="/wiki/Property_tax" title="Property tax">property tax</a>. Generally, properties that are owned and used by religious, charitable, or educational organizations or property owned by the federal, state or local governments are exempt. Property tax rates vary widely. No restrictions or limitations on property taxes are imposed by the state, meaning cities and counties can set tax rates at the level they deem necessary to fund governmental services. These rates can increase, decrease or remain the same from year to year. If the proposed tax rate increases the total property tax revenues, the governing body must advertise that fact and hold a public hearing on the new tax rate. This is called the Constant Yield Tax Rate process.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Biotechnology">Biotechnology</span></h3>
<p>Maryland is a major center for <a href="/wiki/Life_sciences" title="Life sciences">life sciences</a> research and development.  With more than 400 biotechnology companies located there, Maryland is the fourth-largest nexus in this field in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup>
</p><p>Institutions and government agencies with an interest in research and development located in Maryland include the <a href="/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_University" title="Johns Hopkins University">Johns Hopkins University</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Johns_Hopkins_Applied_Physics_Laboratory&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory (page does not exist)">Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory</a>, more than one campus of the <a href="/wiki/University_System_of_Maryland" title="University System of Maryland">University System of Maryland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goddard_Space_Flight_Center" title="Goddard Space Flight Center">Goddard Space Flight Center</a>, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau" title="United States Census Bureau">United States Census Bureau</a>, the <a href="/wiki/National_Institutes_of_Health" title="National Institutes of Health">National Institutes of Health</a> (NIH), the <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Standards_and_Technology" title="National Institute of Standards and Technology">National Institute of Standards and Technology</a> (NIST), the <a href="/wiki/National_Institute_of_Mental_Health" title="National Institute of Mental Health">National Institute of Mental Health</a> (NIMH), the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Military_Medical_Center&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Military Medical Center (page does not exist)">National Military Medical Center</a>, the federal <a href="/wiki/Food_and_Drug_Administration" title="Food and Drug Administration">Food and Drug Administration</a> (FDA), the <a href="/wiki/Howard_Hughes_Medical_Institute" title="Howard Hughes Medical Institute">Howard Hughes Medical Institute</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Celera_Genomics&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Celera Genomics (page does not exist)">Celera Genomics</a> company, <a href="/wiki/Human_Genome_Sciences" title="Human Genome Sciences">Human Genome Sciences</a> (HGS),the <a href="/wiki/J._Craig_Venter_Institute" title="J. Craig Venter Institute">J. Craig Venter Institute</a> (JCVI), and <a href="/wiki/MedImmune" title="MedImmune">MedImmune</a> - recently purchased by <a href="/wiki/AstraZeneca" title="AstraZeneca">AstraZeneca</a>.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Transportation">Transportation</span></h2>
<p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryland_Department_of_Transportation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryland Department of Transportation (page does not exist)">Maryland Department of Transportation</a>, headquartered in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hanover,_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hanover, Maryland (page does not exist)">Hanover</a> area of <a href="/wiki/Unincorporated_area" title="Unincorporated area">unincorporated</a> <a href="/wiki/Anne_Arundel_County,_Maryland" title="Anne Arundel County, Maryland">Anne Arundel County</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> oversees most transportation in the state through its various administration-level agencies. The independent <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Transportation_Authority" title="Maryland Transportation Authority">Maryland Transportation Authority</a>, headquartered in Baltimore, maintains and operates the state's eight toll facilities.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Roads">Roads</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_Maryland_NA.png" title="File:Map of Maryland NA.png">File:Map of Maryland NA.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Maryland's major cities and roads.</div></div></div>
<p>Maryland's <a href="/wiki/Interstate_Highway_System" title="Interstate Highway System">Interstate highways</a> include <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Interstate_95_in_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Interstate 95 in Maryland (page does not exist)">I-95</a>, which enters the northeast portion of the state, goes through <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore (page does not exist)">Baltimore</a>, and becomes part of the eastern section of the <a href="/wiki/Interstate_495_(Capital_Beltway)" title="Interstate 495 (Capital Beltway)">Capital Beltway</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Woodrow_Wilson_Bridge" title="Woodrow Wilson Bridge">Woodrow Wilson Bridge</a>. <a href="/wiki/Interstate_68" title="Interstate 68">I-68</a> runs <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> connecting the western portions of the state to <a href="/wiki/Interstate_70" title="Interstate 70">I-70</a> at the small town of Hancock. <a href="/wiki/Interstate_70" title="Interstate 70">I-70</a> enters from Pennsylvania north of Hancock and continues east for <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> to Baltimore, connecting <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hagerstown,_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hagerstown, Maryland (page does not exist)">Hagerstown</a> and <a href="/wiki/Frederick,_Maryland" title="Frederick, Maryland">Frederick</a> along the way.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Interstate_83" title="Interstate 83">I-83</a> has <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> in Maryland and connects Baltimore to southern central Pennsylvania (<a href="/wiki/Harrisburg,_Pennsylvania" title="Harrisburg, Pennsylvania">Harrisburg</a> and <a href="/wiki/York,_Pennsylvania" title="York, Pennsylvania">York, Pennsylvania</a>). Maryland also has an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> portion of <a href="/wiki/Interstate_81" title="Interstate 81">I-81</a> that runs through the state near Hagerstown. <a href="/wiki/Interstate_97" title="Interstate 97">I-97</a>, fully contained within Anne Arundel County and the second shortest (17.6 miles) one- or two-digit Interstate highway which connects the Baltimore area to the Annapolis area. Hawaii has one that is shorter.
</p><p>There are also several <a href="/wiki/List_of_auxiliary_Interstate_Highways" title="List of auxiliary Interstate Highways">auxiliary Interstate highways</a> in Maryland. Among them are two beltways encircling the major cities of the region: <a href="/wiki/Interstate_695_(Maryland)" title="Interstate 695 (Maryland)">I-695</a>, the McKeldin (Baltimore) Beltway, which encircles Baltimore; and a portion of <a href="/wiki/Interstate_495_(Capital_Beltway)" title="Interstate 495 (Capital Beltway)">I-495</a>, the Capital Beltway, which encircles Washington, D.C. <a href="/wiki/Interstate_270_(Maryland)" title="Interstate 270 (Maryland)">I-270</a>, which connects the Frederick area with Northern Virginia and the District of Columbia through major suburbs to the northwest of Washington, is a major commuter route and is as wide as fourteen lanes at points.
</p><p>Both I-270 and the Capital Beltway are currently extremely <a href="/wiki/Traffic_congestion" title="Traffic congestion">congested</a>; however, the <b><a href="/w/index.php?title=Intercounty_Connector&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Intercounty Connector (page does not exist)">ICC</a></b> or <b>I</b>nter<b>c</b>ounty <b>C</b>onnector (MD 200) is hoped to alleviate some of the congestion over time. Construction of the ICC was a major part of the campaign platform of former Governor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Ehrlich&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert Ehrlich (page does not exist)">Robert Ehrlich</a>, who was in office from 2003 until 2007, and of Governor <a href="/wiki/Martin_O%27Malley" title="Martin O'Malley">Martin O'Malley</a>, who succeeded him. <a href="/wiki/Interstate_595_(Maryland)" title="Interstate 595 (Maryland)">I-595</a>, which is concurrent with <a href="/w/index.php?title=U.S._Route_50_in_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U.S. Route 50 in Maryland (page does not exist)">US 50</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=U.S._Route_301_in_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="U.S. Route 301 in Maryland (page does not exist)">US 301</a>, is the longest <a href="/w/index.php?title=Unsigned_highway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Unsigned highway (page does not exist)">unsigned</a> interstate in the country and connects <a href="/wiki/Prince_George%27s_County,_Maryland" title="Prince George's County, Maryland">Prince George's County</a> and <a href="/wiki/Washington_D.C." title="Washington D.C." class="mw-redirect">Washington D.C.</a> with <a href="/wiki/Annapolis" title="Annapolis" class="mw-redirect">Annapolis</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Shore_of_Maryland" title="Eastern Shore of Maryland">Eastern Shore</a> via the <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay_Bridge" title="Chesapeake Bay Bridge">Chesapeake Bay Bridge</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Chesapeake_Bay_Bridge.jpg" title="File:Chesapeake Bay Bridge.jpg">File:Chesapeake Bay Bridge.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_Bay_Bridge" title="Chesapeake Bay Bridge">Chesapeake Bay Bridge</a>, which connects Maryland's <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Shore_of_Maryland" title="Eastern Shore of Maryland">Eastern</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Western_Shore&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Western Shore (page does not exist)">Western</a> Shores, is the most popular route for tourists to reach the resort town of <a href="/wiki/Ocean_City,_Maryland" title="Ocean City, Maryland">Ocean City</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Maryland also has a <a href="/wiki/State_highway" title="State highway">state highway</a> system that contains routes numbered from 2 through 999, however most of the higher-numbered routes are either not signed or are relatively short. Major state highways include Routes <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Route_2" title="Maryland Route 2">2</a> (Governor Ritchie Highway/Solomons Island Road/Southern Maryland Blvd.), <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Route_4" title="Maryland Route 4">4</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Pennsylvania_Avenue&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pennsylvania Avenue (page does not exist)">Pennsylvania Avenue</a>/Southern Maryland Blvd./Patuxent Beach Road/St. Andrew's Church Road), <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Route_5" title="Maryland Route 5">5</a> (Branch Avenue/Leonardtown Road/Point Lookout Road), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryland_Route_32&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryland Route 32 (page does not exist)">32</a>, <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Route_45" title="Maryland Route 45">45</a> (York Road), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryland_Route_97&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryland Route 97 (page does not exist)">97</a> (Georgia Avenue), <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Route_100" title="Maryland Route 100">100</a> (Paul T. Pitcher Memorial Highway), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryland_Route_210&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryland Route 210 (page does not exist)">210</a> (Indian Head Highway), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryland_Route_235&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryland Route 235 (page does not exist)">235</a> (Three Notch Road), <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Route_295" title="Maryland Route 295" class="mw-redirect">295</a> (Baltimore-Washington Parkway), <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryland_Route_355&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryland Route 355 (page does not exist)">355</a> (Wisconsin Avenue/Rockville Pike/Frederick Road),  <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Route_404" title="Maryland Route 404">404</a> (Queen Anne Highway/ Shore Highway), and
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryland_Route_650&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryland Route 650 (page does not exist)">650</a> (New Hampshire Avenue).
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Airports">Airports</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
Maryland's largest airport is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore-Washington_International_Thurgood_Marshall_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore-Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport (page does not exist)">Baltimore-Washington International Thurgood Marshall Airport</a> (known as Friendship Airport from its construction in 1950 and  renamed in 2005 for Baltimore-born former and first African-American Supreme Court Justice <a href="/wiki/Thurgood_Marshall" title="Thurgood Marshall">Thurgood Marshall</a>). The only other airports with commercial service are at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hagerstown_Regional_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hagerstown Regional Airport (page does not exist)">Hagerstown</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Wicomico_Regional_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Wicomico Regional Airport (page does not exist)">Salisbury</a>. The Maryland suburbs of Washington, D.C. are also serviced by the other two airports in the region, <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Reagan_Washington_National_Airport" title="Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport">Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/Dulles_International_Airport" title="Dulles International Airport" class="mw-redirect">Dulles International Airport</a>, both in <a href="/wiki/Northern_Virginia" title="Northern Virginia">Northern Virginia</a>.  The <a href="/w/index.php?title=College_Park_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="College Park Airport (page does not exist)">College Park Airport</a> is the nation's oldest, founded in 1909, and is still utilized.  Wilbur Wright trained military aviators at this location.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rail">Rail</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/wiki/Amtrak" title="Amtrak">Amtrak</a> trains, including the high speed <a href="/wiki/Acela_Express" title="Acela Express">Acela Express</a> serve Baltimore's <a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Station_(Baltimore)" title="Pennsylvania Station (Baltimore)">Penn Station</a>, <a href="/wiki/BWI_Rail_Station" title="BWI Rail Station">BWI Airport</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Carrollton_(Washington_Metro)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Carrollton (Washington Metro) (page does not exist)">New Carrollton</a>, and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Aberdeen_(Amtrak_station)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Aberdeen (Amtrak station) (page does not exist)">Aberdeen</a> along the <a href="/wiki/Washington_D.C." title="Washington D.C." class="mw-redirect">Washington D.C.</a> to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Boston&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Boston (page does not exist)">Boston</a> <a href="/wiki/Northeast_Corridor" title="Northeast Corridor">Northeast Corridor</a>. In addition, train service is provided to <a href="/wiki/Rockville,_Maryland" title="Rockville, Maryland">Rockville</a> and <a href="/wiki/Cumberland,_Maryland" title="Cumberland, Maryland">Cumberland</a> by Amtrak's Washington, D.C., to <a href="/wiki/Chicago" title="Chicago">Chicago</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Capitol_Limited_(Amtrak)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Capitol Limited (Amtrak) (page does not exist)">Capitol Limited</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Ellicott_City_Station_1970.jpg" title="File:Ellicott City Station 1970.jpg">File:Ellicott City Station 1970.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/w/index.php?title=Ellicott_City_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ellicott City Station (page does not exist)">Ellicott City Station</a>, on the original B&amp;O Railroad line, is the oldest remaining passenger station in the United States. The rail line is still used by <a href="/wiki/CSX_Transportation" title="CSX Transportation">CSX Transportation</a> for freight trains, and the station is now a museum.</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/WMATA" title="WMATA" class="mw-redirect">WMATA's</a> <a href="/wiki/Washington_Metro" title="Washington Metro">Metrorail</a> <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rapid_transit&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rapid transit (page does not exist)">rapid transit</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Metrobus_(Washington,_D.C.)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Metrobus (Washington, D.C.) (page does not exist)">Metrobus</a> local bus systems (the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_United_States_rapid_transit_systems_by_ridership&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of United States rapid transit systems by ridership (page does not exist)">2nd</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_United_States_local_bus_agencies_by_ridership&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of United States local bus agencies by ridership (page does not exist)">6th</a> busiest in the nation of their respective modes) provide service in Montgomery and Prince George's counties and connect them to Washington D.C., with the express Metrobus <a href="/w/index.php?title=Route_B30_(WMATA)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Route B30 (WMATA) (page does not exist)"><i>Route B30</i></a> serving <a href="/w/index.php?title=BWI_Thurgood_Marshall_Airport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="BWI Thurgood Marshall Airport (page does not exist)">BWI Airport</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Transit_Administration" title="Maryland Transit Administration">Maryland Transit Administration</a> (often abbreviated as "MTA Maryland"), a state agency part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryland_Department_of_Transportation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryland Department of Transportation (page does not exist)">Maryland Department of Transportation</a> also provides transit services within the state. Headquartered in Baltimore, MTA's transit services are largely focused on central Maryland, as well as  some portions of the Eastern Shore and Southern MD. Baltimore's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore_Light_Rail&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore Light Rail (page does not exist)">Light Rail</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore_Metro_Subway&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore Metro Subway (page does not exist)">Metro Subway</a> systems serve its densely populated inner-city and the surrounding suburbs. The MTA also serves the city and its suburbs with its <a href="/w/index.php?title=MTA_Maryland_bus_service&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="MTA Maryland bus service (page does not exist)">local bus</a> service (the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_United_States_local_bus_agencies_by_ridership&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of United States local bus agencies by ridership (page does not exist)">9th largest system</a> in the nation). The MTA's <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Transit_Administration#Commuter_bus" title="Maryland Transit Administration">Commuter Bus</a> system provides express coach service on longer routes connecting Washington D.C. and Baltimore to parts of Central and Southern MD as well as the Eastern Shore. The commuter rail service, known as <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Area_Rail_Commuter" title="Maryland Area Rail Commuter" class="mw-redirect">MARC</a>, operates three lines which all terminate at <a href="/wiki/Washington_Union_Station" title="Washington Union Station" class="mw-redirect">Washington Union Station</a> and provide service to Baltimore's <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_Penn_Station" title="Baltimore Penn Station" class="mw-redirect">Penn</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Camden_Station&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Camden Station (page does not exist)">Camden</a> stations, <a href="/wiki/Perryville,_Maryland" title="Perryville, Maryland">Perryville</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frederick,_Maryland" title="Frederick, Maryland">Frederick</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Martinsburg,_West_Virginia" title="Martinsburg, West Virginia">Martinsburg, WV</a>. In addition, many suburban counties operate their own local bus systems which connect to and complement the larger MTA and WMATA/Metro services.
</p><p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Freight_rail_transport&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Freight rail transport (page does not exist)">Freight rail transport</a> is handled principally by two <a href="/w/index.php?title=Class_I_railroad&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Class I railroad (page does not exist)">Class I railroads</a>, as well as several smaller regional and local carriers. <a href="/wiki/CSX_Transportation" title="CSX Transportation">CSX Transportation</a> has more extensive <a href="/w/index.php?title=Rail_tracks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Rail tracks (page does not exist)">trackage</a> throughout the state, with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-CSXT_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CSXT-93">[93]</a></sup> followed by <a href="/wiki/Norfolk_Southern_Railway" title="Norfolk Southern Railway">Norfolk Southern Railway</a>. Major <a href="/wiki/Rail_yard" title="Rail yard">rail yards</a> are located in Baltimore and Cumberland,<sup id="cite_ref-CSXT_93-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CSXT-93">[93]</a></sup> with an <a href="/wiki/Intermodal_freight_transport" title="Intermodal freight transport">intermodal</a> terminal (rail, truck and marine) in Baltimore.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Shipping_canals">Shipping canals</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Chesapeake_and_Delaware_Canal" title="Chesapeake and Delaware Canal">Chesapeake and Delaware Canal</a> is a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> <a href="/wiki/Canal" title="Canal">canal</a> on the Eastern Shore that connects the waters of the Delaware River with those of the Chesapeake Bay, and in particular with the Port of Baltimore, carrying 40 percent of the port's ship traffic.<sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_government">Law and government</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Maryland_quarter,_reverse_side,_2000.jpg" title="File:Maryland quarter, reverse side, 2000.jpg">File:Maryland quarter, reverse side, 2000.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The reverse side of the Maryland quarter shows the dome of the State House in Annapolis.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Maryland" title="Government of Maryland">government of Maryland</a> is conducted according to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryland_Constitution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryland Constitution (page does not exist)">state constitution</a>. The government of Maryland, like the other 49 <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_the_United_States#State_government" title="Politics of the United States">state governments</a>, has exclusive authority over matters that lie entirely within the state's borders, except as limited by the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_States" title="Constitution of the United States" class="mw-redirect">Constitution of the United States</a>.
</p><p>Power in Maryland is divided among three branches of government: <a href="/wiki/Executive_branch" title="Executive branch" class="mw-redirect">executive</a>, <a href="/wiki/Legislative_branch" title="Legislative branch" class="mw-redirect">legislative</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Judicial_branch" title="Judicial branch" class="mw-redirect">judicial</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Maryland_General_Assembly" title="Maryland General Assembly">Maryland General Assembly</a> is composed of the <a href="/wiki/Maryland_House_of_Delegates" title="Maryland House of Delegates">Maryland House of Delegates</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Senate" title="Maryland Senate">Maryland Senate</a>. <a href="/wiki/Governor_of_Maryland" title="Governor of Maryland">Maryland's governor</a> is unique in the United States as the office is vested with significant authority in budgeting. The legislature may not increase the governor's proposed budget expenditures. Unlike most other states, significant autonomy is granted to many of Maryland's <a href="/wiki/County_(United_States)" title="County (United States)">counties</a>.
</p><p>Most of the business of government is conducted in <a href="/wiki/Annapolis,_Maryland" title="Annapolis, Maryland">Annapolis</a>, the state <a href="/w/index.php?title=Capital_(political)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Capital (political) (page does not exist)">capital</a>. Virtually all state and county <a href="/wiki/Election" title="Election">elections</a> are held in even-numbered years not divisible by four, in which the <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">President of the United States</a> is not elected&#160;– this, as in other states, is intended to divide state and <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States" title="Federal government of the United States">federal</a> politics.
</p><p>The judicial branch of state government consists of one united District Court of Maryland that sits in every county and Baltimore City, as well as 24 Circuit Courts sitting in each County and Baltimore City, the latter being courts of general jurisdiction for all civil disputes over $30,000.00, all equitable jurisdiction and major criminal proceedings. The intermediate appellate court is known as the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryland_Court_of_Special_Appeals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryland Court of Special Appeals (page does not exist)">Court of Special Appeals</a>" and the <a href="/wiki/State_supreme_court" title="State supreme court">state supreme court</a> is the "<a href="/wiki/Maryland_Court_of_Appeals" title="Maryland Court of Appeals">Court of Appeals</a>". The appearance of the judges of the Maryland Court of Appeals is unique; Maryland is the only state whose judges wear red robes.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Elections">Elections</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Further2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Further2 (page does not exist)">Template:Further2</a>
</p><p>Since before the Civil War, Maryland's elections have been largely controlled by the <a href="/wiki/U.S._Democratic_Party" title="U.S. Democratic Party" class="mw-redirect">Democrats</a>, even as the party's <a href="/wiki/Party_platform" title="Party platform">platform</a> has changed considerably in that time. State elections are dominated by Baltimore and the populous suburban counties bordering <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>: <a href="/wiki/Montgomery_County,_Maryland" title="Montgomery County, Maryland">Montgomery</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prince_George%27s_County,_Maryland" title="Prince George's County, Maryland">Prince George's</a>. Forty-three percent of the state's population resides in these three jurisdictions, each of which contain large, traditionally Democratic <a href="/wiki/Voting_bloc" title="Voting bloc">voting bloc(s)</a>: <a href="/wiki/African_Americans" title="African Americans" class="mw-redirect">African Americans</a> in Baltimore and Prince George's, <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States" title="Federal government of the United States">federal</a> employees in Prince George's and Montgomery, and <a href="/wiki/Postgraduate_education" title="Postgraduate education">postgraduates</a> in Montgomery. The remainder of the state, particularly <a href="/wiki/Western_Maryland" title="Western Maryland">Western Maryland</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Shore_of_Maryland" title="Eastern Shore of Maryland">Eastern Shore</a>, is more supportive of <a href="/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)" title="Republican Party (United States)">Republicans</a>.
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Spiro_Agnew.jpg" title="File:Spiro Agnew.jpg">File:Spiro Agnew.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Spiro_Agnew" title="Spiro Agnew">Spiro Agnew</a>, former <a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States" title="Vice President of the United States">Vice President of the United States</a> and the highest-ranking political leader from Maryland since the founding of the United States.</div></div></div>
<p>Maryland has supported the Democratic nominee in each of the last five presidential elections, by an average margin of 15.4 percent. In 1980, it was one of six states to vote for <a href="/wiki/Jimmy_Carter" title="Jimmy Carter">Jimmy Carter</a>. In recent years, Maryland has been among the most reliable states for Democratic nominees. In 1992, <a href="/wiki/Bill_Clinton" title="Bill Clinton">Bill Clinton</a> fared better in Maryland than any other state except his home state of <a href="/wiki/Arkansas" title="Arkansas">Arkansas</a>. In 1996, Maryland was Clinton's sixth best, in 2000 Maryland ranked fourth for Gore and in 2004 <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Kerry&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Kerry (page does not exist)">John Kerry</a> showed his fifth best performance in Maryland.  In 2008, <a href="/wiki/Barack_Obama" title="Barack Obama">Barack Obama</a> won the state's 10 electoral votes with 61.9 percent of the vote to <a href="/wiki/John_McCain" title="John McCain">John McCain's</a> 36.5 percent.
</p><p>While Republicans usually win more counties by piling up large margins in the west and east, they are usually swamped by the more densely populated and heavily Democratic Baltimore-Washington axis.  In 2008, for instance, McCain won 17 counties to Obama's six; Obama also carried Baltimore City.  While McCain won most of the western and eastern counties by margins of 2-to-1 or more, he was almost completely shut out in the larger counties surrounding Baltimore and Washington; every large county except Anne Arundel went for Obama.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p><p>Both of Maryland's U.S. Senators and seven of its eight Representatives in Congress are Democrats, and Democrats hold a <a href="/wiki/Supermajority" title="Supermajority">supermajority</a> in the state Senate. The previous Governor, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Ehrlich&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert Ehrlich (page does not exist)">Robert Ehrlich</a>, was the first Republican to be elected to that office in four decades, and after one term lost his seat to Baltimore <a href="/wiki/Mayor" title="Mayor">Mayor</a> Martin J. O'Malley, a Democrat.  Ehrlich ran again for Governor in 2010, losing again to O'Malley.
</p><p>U.S. Congressman <a href="/wiki/Steny_Hoyer" title="Steny Hoyer">Steny Hoyer</a> (<a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryland%27s_5th_congressional_district&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryland's 5th congressional district (page does not exist)">MD-5</a>), a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Democratic_Party_(United_States)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Democratic Party (United States) (page does not exist)">Democrat</a>, was elected as <a href="/wiki/Majority_Leader" title="Majority Leader" class="mw-redirect">Majority Leader</a> for the <a href="/wiki/110th_United_States_Congress" title="110th United States Congress">110th Congress</a> of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=United_States_House_of_Representatives&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="United States House of Representatives (page does not exist)">House of Representatives</a>, and <a href="/wiki/111th_United_States_Congress" title="111th United States Congress">111th Congress</a>, serving in that post from 2007 to 2011. His district covers parts of <a href="/wiki/Anne_Arundel_County,_Maryland" title="Anne Arundel County, Maryland">Anne Arundel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Prince_George%27s_County,_Maryland" title="Prince George's County, Maryland">Prince George's</a> counties, in addition to all of <a href="/wiki/Charles_County,_Maryland" title="Charles County, Maryland">Charles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Calvert_County,_Maryland" title="Calvert County, Maryland">Calvert</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Saint_Mary%27s_County,_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Saint Mary's County, Maryland (page does not exist)">St. Mary's</a> counties in <a href="/wiki/Southern_Maryland" title="Southern Maryland">southern Maryland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 2006 election brought no significant change in this pattern of Democratic dominance. After Democratic Senator <a href="/wiki/Paul_Sarbanes" title="Paul Sarbanes">Paul Sarbanes</a> announced that he was retiring, Democratic Congressman <a href="/w/index.php?title=Benjamin_Cardin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Benjamin Cardin (page does not exist)">Benjamin Cardin</a> defeated Republican Lieutenant Governor <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_S._Steele&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael S. Steele (page does not exist)">Michael S. Steele</a>, with 55 percent of the vote, against Steele's 44 percent.
</p><p>While Maryland is a Democratic Party stronghold, perhaps its best known political figure is a Republican&#160;– former Governor <a href="/wiki/Spiro_Agnew" title="Spiro Agnew">Spiro Agnew</a>, who served as United States Vice President under <a href="/wiki/Richard_Nixon" title="Richard Nixon">Richard Nixon</a>. He was Vice President from 1969 to 1973, when he resigned in the aftermath of revelations that he had taken <a href="/wiki/Bribes" title="Bribes" class="mw-redirect">bribes</a> while he was Governor of Maryland. In late 1973, a court found Agnew guilty of violating tax laws.
</p><p>In 2010 Republicans won control of most counties. The Democratic Party remained in control of eight county governments including <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_City" title="Baltimore City" class="mw-redirect">Baltimore City</a>.{{ safesubst:#invoke:Unsubst||$N=Citation needed |date=__DATE__ |$B=
<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Fix&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Fix (page does not exist)">Template:Fix</a>
}}
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education">Education</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Primary_and_secondary_education">Primary and secondary education</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Memorial_Chapel_at_UMCP,_front_view_off-center,_August_21,_2006.jpg" title="File:Memorial Chapel at UMCP, front view off-center, August 21, 2006.jpg">File:Memorial Chapel at UMCP, front view off-center, August 21, 2006.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Memorial Chapel at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Maryland,_College_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Maryland, College Park (page does not exist)">University of Maryland, College Park</a>, Maryland's largest university.</div></div></div>
