<p>Education Week ranked Maryland #1 in its nationwide 2009-2013 Quality Counts reports.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cn (page does not exist)">Template:Cn</a> The College Board's 9th Annual AP Report to the Nation also ranked Maryland first.<a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Cn&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Cn (page does not exist)">Template:Cn</a> Primary and secondary education in Maryland is overseen by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Maryland_State_Department_of_Education&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Maryland State Department of Education (page does not exist)">Maryland State Department of Education</a>, which is headquartered in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore,_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore, Maryland (page does not exist)">Baltimore</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> The highest educational official in the state is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Superintendent_(education)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Superintendent (education) (page does not exist)">State Superintendent of Schools</a>, who is appointed by the <a href="/wiki/Board_of_education" title="Board of education">State Board of Education</a> to a four-year term of office. The Maryland General Assembly has given the Superintendent and State Board autonomy to make educationally related decisions, limiting its own influence on the day to day functions of public education. Each county and county-equivalent in Maryland has a <a href="/wiki/List_of_school_districts_in_Maryland" title="List of school districts in Maryland">local Board of Education</a> charged with running the public schools in that particular jurisdiction.
</p><p>The budget for education was $5.5 billion in 2009, representing about 40 percent of the state's general fund.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup>
</p><p>Maryland has a broad range of private primary and secondary schools. Many of these are affiliated with various religious sects, including <a href="/wiki/Parochial_schools" title="Parochial schools" class="mw-redirect">parochial schools</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Catholic_Church" title="Catholic Church">Catholic Church</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Quaker&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Quaker (page does not exist)">Quaker</a> schools, <a href="/wiki/Seventh-day_Adventist_Church" title="Seventh-day Adventist Church">Seventh-day Adventist</a> schools, and <a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Jewish</a> schools. In 2003, Maryland law was changed to allow for the creation of publicly funded charter schools, although the charter schools must be approved by their local Board of Education and are not exempt from state laws on education, including collective bargaining laws.
</p><p>In 2008, the state led the entire country in the percentage of students passing <a href="/wiki/Advanced_Placement" title="Advanced Placement">Advanced Placement</a> examinations. 23.4 percent of students earned passing grades on the AP tests given in May 2008. This marks the first year that Maryland earned this honor.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> Three Maryland high schools (in Montgomery County) were ranked among the top 100 in the country by US News in 2009, based in large part on AP test scores.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Colleges_and_universities">Colleges and universities</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>Maryland has several historic and renowned private colleges and universities, the most prominent of which is <a href="/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_University" title="Johns Hopkins University">Johns Hopkins University</a>, founded in 1876 with a grant from Baltimore entrepreneur <a href="/wiki/Johns_Hopkins" title="Johns Hopkins">Johns Hopkins</a>.
</p><p>The first public university in the state is the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Maryland,_Baltimore" title="University of Maryland, Baltimore">University of Maryland, Baltimore</a>, which was founded in 1807 and contains the University of Maryland's only public academic <a href="/wiki/University_of_Maryland_School_of_Medicine" title="University of Maryland School of Medicine" class="mw-redirect">health</a>, human services, and one of two <a href="/wiki/University_of_Maryland_School_of_Law" title="University of Maryland School of Law">law centers</a> (the other being the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Baltimore_School_of_Law&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Baltimore School of Law (page does not exist)">University of Baltimore School of Law</a>). Seven professional and graduate schools train the majority of the state's physicians, nurses, dentists, lawyers, social workers, and pharmacists.<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup> The largest undergraduate institution in Maryland is the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Maryland,_College_Park&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Maryland, College Park (page does not exist)">University of Maryland, College Park</a> which was founded as the Maryland Agricultural College in 1856 and became a public <a href="/wiki/Land_grant_college" title="Land grant college" class="mw-redirect">land grant college</a> in 1864. <a href="/wiki/Towson_University" title="Towson University">Towson University</a>, founded in 1866, is the state's second largest university. Baltimore is home to the <a href="/wiki/Maryland_Institute_College_of_Art" title="Maryland Institute College of Art">Maryland Institute College of Art</a>. The majority of public universities in the state are affiliated with the <a href="/wiki/University_System_of_Maryland" title="University System of Maryland">University System of Maryland</a>. Two state-funded institutions, <a href="/wiki/Morgan_State_University" title="Morgan State University">Morgan State University</a> and <a href="/wiki/St._Mary%27s_College_of_Maryland" title="St. Mary's College of Maryland">St. Mary's College of Maryland</a>, as well as two federally funded institutions, the <a href="/wiki/Uniformed_Services_University_of_the_Health_Sciences" title="Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences">Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences</a> and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Naval_Academy" title="United States Naval Academy">United States Naval Academy</a>, are not affiliated with the University System of Maryland.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/St._John%27s_College_(Annapolis/Santa_Fe)" title="St. John's College (Annapolis/Santa Fe)">St. John's College</a> in <a href="/wiki/Annapolis,_Maryland" title="Annapolis, Maryland">Annapolis, Maryland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Washington_College" title="Washington College">Washington College</a> in <a href="/wiki/Chestertown,_Maryland" title="Chestertown, Maryland">Chestertown, Maryland</a>, both private institutions, are the two oldest colleges in the state, and are among the oldest in the country.  Other private institutions include <a href="/wiki/Mount_St._Mary%27s_University" title="Mount St. Mary's University">Mount St. Mary's University</a>, <a href="/wiki/McDaniel_College" title="McDaniel College">McDaniel College</a> (formerly known as Western Maryland College), <a href="/wiki/Hood_College" title="Hood College">Hood College</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stevenson_University" title="Stevenson University">Stevenson University</a> (formerly known as Villa Julie College), <a href="/wiki/Loyola_University_Maryland" title="Loyola University Maryland">Loyola University Maryland</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goucher_College" title="Goucher College">Goucher College</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Salisbury_University" title="Salisbury University">Salisbury University</a> among others.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:CamdenYards_2005-05-08.jpg" title="File:CamdenYards 2005-05-08.jpg">File:CamdenYards 2005-05-08.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Oriole_Park_at_Camden_Yards" title="Oriole Park at Camden Yards">Oriole Park at Camden Yards</a>, home of the <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_Orioles" title="Baltimore Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:M%26T_Bank_Stadium_DoD.jpg" title="File:M&amp;T Bank Stadium DoD.jpg">File:M&amp;T Bank Stadium DoD.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/M%26T_Bank_Stadium" title="M&amp;T Bank Stadium">M&amp;T Bank Stadium</a>, home of the <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_Ravens" title="Baltimore Ravens">Baltimore Ravens</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:See_also2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:See also2 (page does not exist)">Template:See also2</a>
With two major metropolitan areas, Maryland has a number of major and minor professional sports franchises. Two <a href="/wiki/National_Football_League" title="National Football League">National Football League</a> teams play in Maryland, the <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_Ravens" title="Baltimore Ravens">Baltimore Ravens</a> in <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore,_Maryland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore, Maryland (page does not exist)">Baltimore City</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Washington_Redskins" title="Washington Redskins">Washington Redskins</a> in <a href="/wiki/Landover,_Maryland" title="Landover, Maryland">Landover</a>. The <a href="/w/index.php?title=History_of_the_Baltimore_Colts&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="History of the Baltimore Colts (page does not exist)">Baltimore Colts</a> represented the NFL in Baltimore from 1953 to 1983 before moving to <a href="/wiki/Indianapolis" title="Indianapolis">Indianapolis</a>.
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Baltimore_Orioles" title="Baltimore Orioles">Baltimore Orioles</a> are the state's <a href="/wiki/Major_League_Baseball" title="Major League Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> franchise. The <a href="/wiki/National_Hockey_League" title="National Hockey League">National Hockey League</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Washington_Capitals" title="Washington Capitals">Washington Capitals</a> and the <a href="/wiki/National_Basketball_Association" title="National Basketball Association">National Basketball Association</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Washington_Wizards" title="Washington Wizards">Washington Wizards</a> formerly played in Maryland, until the construction of an arena in Downtown D.C. in 1997 (originally known as MCI Center, renamed <a href="/wiki/Verizon_Center" title="Verizon Center">Verizon Center</a> in 2006).
</p><p>Maryland enjoys considerable historical repute for the talented sports players of its past, including <a href="/wiki/Cal_Ripken_Jr." title="Cal Ripken Jr." class="mw-redirect">Cal Ripken Jr.</a> and <a href="/wiki/Babe_Ruth" title="Babe Ruth">Babe Ruth</a>. In 2012, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Baltimore_Sun" title="The Baltimore Sun">The Baltimore Sun</a></i> published a list of Maryland's top ten athletes in the state's history. The list includes Ruth, Ripken, <a href="/wiki/Johnny_Unitas" title="Johnny Unitas">Johnny Unitas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brooks_Robinson" title="Brooks Robinson">Brooks Robinson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frank_Robinson" title="Frank Robinson">Frank Robinson</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ray_Lewis" title="Ray Lewis">Ray Lewis</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Michael_Phelps&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Michael Phelps (page does not exist)">Michael Phelps</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jimmie_Foxx" title="Jimmie Foxx">Jimmie Foxx</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jim_Parker_(American_football)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jim Parker (American football) (page does not exist)">Jim Parker</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Wes_Unseld" title="Wes Unseld">Wes Unseld</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other professional sports franchises in the state include five affiliated <a href="/wiki/Minor_league_baseball" title="Minor league baseball" class="mw-redirect">minor league baseball</a> teams, one <a href="/w/index.php?title=Independent_league_baseball&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Independent league baseball (page does not exist)">independent league baseball</a> team, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Baltimore_Blast_(current)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Baltimore Blast (current) (page does not exist)">Baltimore Blast</a> indoor soccer team, two indoor football teams, and three low-level outdoor soccer teams. Maryland is also home to one of the three races in horse racing's annual Triple Crown, the <a href="/wiki/Preakness_Stakes" title="Preakness Stakes">Preakness Stakes</a>, which is run every spring at <a href="/wiki/Pimlico_Race_Course" title="Pimlico Race Course">Pimlico Race Course</a> in Baltimore.
</p><p>The official state sport of Maryland, since 1962, is <a href="/wiki/Jousting" title="Jousting">jousting</a>; the official team sport since 2004 is <a href="/wiki/Lacrosse" title="Lacrosse">lacrosse</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-105" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-105">[105]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Lacrosse_Hall_of_Fame&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Lacrosse Hall of Fame (page does not exist)">National Lacrosse Hall of Fame</a> is located on the <a href="/wiki/Johns_Hopkins_University" title="Johns Hopkins University">Johns Hopkins University</a> campus in Baltimore. In 2008, intending to promote physical fitness for all ages, walking became the official state exercise. Maryland is the first state with an official state exercise.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
